loans.name: Chheng

texts.en: Chheng S., 41, is a farmer with 9 children who lives in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 1988, she has been growing and selling rice to earn approximately US$2 every day, while her husband makes US$2 as a palm climber. Every day, her husband goes to collect palm juice and refines it into palm sugar. Chheng recently has requested a loan to make a new investment. She will use the money to raise ducks so she can sell the eggs.

loans.use: To raise ducks.

loans.name: Mrs. Sreang Lang Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of eleven people, is located in Trapang Buon village in Kampong Chhnang province. Mrs. Sreang L. is a village bank borrower that has been selected by the group members and the loan will be used for many different purposes. For instance, Mrs. Sreang L. is requesting the loan to buy more fish for her current business which is going well. Her husband, Mr. Mao Da, is a farmer who owns 1.5-hectar and cultivates rice for a living. Mrs. Sreang L. is 42 years old and the mother of five children. Two of the children help their father with the farming while the remaining three are attending the local school. Mrs. Kmao Ur and Mrs. Voeurn M. who are group guarantors are also presented in the picture with other village bank members.

Eight members in this village bank loan are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthL. payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financialL. able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of onL. 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase fish to sell.

loans.name: Ha's Group

texts.vi:
Trương Thị Hà sinh năm 1983,( Mã số: 010103080001) Chị là thợ may, chồng làm cơ khí có T. nhập ổn định. Bên cạnh đó, vợ chồng chị vẫn tăng gia sản xuất, chăn nuôi gà, vịt. T. nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 4.000.000 vnđ/tháng. Chị tham gia vay vốn với mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi. Chị được mọi người tin tưởng, tín nhiệm và bầu làm nhóm trưởng nhóm vay vốn. Cùng vay với chị còn có:
 Lê Thị Lý sinh năm 1966,( Mã số: 010103080002) tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư vật liệu làm cơ khí. T. nhập bình quân của gia đình khoảng 3.500.000 vnđ/tháng.
 Nguyễn Thị M. sinh năm 1976 ,( Mã số: 010103080003)chị có nghề làm đậu có T. nhập theo ngày, T. nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 2.500.000 vnđ/ tháng, Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư nghề phụ.
 Bùi B. N. sinh năm 1976,( Mã số: 010103080004) hàng ngày chị đi chợ bán T.t lợn có T. nhập theo ngày khoảng 150.000 vnđ/ ngày. Chị tham gia vay mức vốn: 3.270.000 vnđ để đi chợ.
 Phan Thị T. Phương sinh năm 1984 ,( Mã số: 010103080005 )chị bán hang quàn áo may sẵn có T. nhập theo ngày khoảng 200.000 vnđ/ ngày. Chị vay mức vốn: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư mở rộng cửa hàng.

loans.use: raising animals

loans.name: Oeun

texts.en: Oeun S. is 43 years old and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She is a professional tailor and has opened a tailor shop in her home to earn a living, and is able to make about US$2 of profit every day. Her husband works as farmer growing rice and vegetables. On average, he makes US$2 per day. She and her husband have four children and all of them are in school. Mrs. Oeun S. has requested a loan to purchase another sewing machine to make her business run more smoothly.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine.

loans.name: Sao Ry

texts.en: Mrs. Sao Ry Y. is a villager in Kan Your village in the Kampong Chhnang province. Mrs. Sao Ry Y. is a 57-year-old widow with two children, one of whom is a farmer while the other one is vegetable seller. She is a farmer who grows lotus in her lake but she faces a problem because she does not have enough money to buy lotus seeds to grow. Mrs. Sao Ry Y. is now requesting a loan to buy lotus seeds and any remaining money will be used to buy fertilizers to support her lotus later.

loans.use: To purchase lotus seeds.

loans.name: Rin

texts.en: Rin S., 26, is a true entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling chickens and rice in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Her business has been operating for about five years, and on average she makes US$2.50 of profit per day. Her husband earns less than one dollar per day by working as a farmer. This couple has two children, both of whom are in school. Mrs. Rin would like to take out a loan to buy more chickens and rice to sell to the market.

loans.use: To buy more chickens and rice to sell.

loans.name: Na

texts.en: Mrs. Na C. was born in 1973 and lives in Andoung Preng village in the Kampong Chhnang province. She is a rice middle man who buys rice to keep in stock to resell later at a better price. Aside from this business, she is a grocer. Since these businesses are doing well, she would like to expand them and is therefore requesting a loan to buy more rice and grocery goods. Her husband, Mr. Sith Chanthou, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land and cultivates rice. Mrs. Na C. has four children two of whom are attending the local school while the remaining two are too young to work or study because they are only three and four years old.

loans.use: To purchase more rice and grocery goods for her business.

loans.name: Mrs. Tom Mil Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of nine people, is located in Hang Chhouk village in the Kampong Chhnang province. All of the members will use this loan for different purposes. Mrs. Tom M. is a village bank president who has been selected by the members. She and her husband, Mr. Kham Sophal, are farmers who own a small piece of land and cultivates rice. The plantation has been yielding a smaller crop due to the infertile soil. To rectify with this problem, Mrs. Tom M. has decided to request a loan to buy fertilizers to support the field and make her crop more productive. Mrs. Tom M. is 41 years old and the mother of six children two of whom are employed in a garment factory, three are attending the local school and the youngest one is only five years old.

Seven members in this village bank loan are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows tH. to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers to support the field and make her crops more productive.

loans.name: Kieu's Group

texts.vi:
Kiều Thị Vĩnh sinh năm 1958,( Mã số: 010103080006) là công nhân đã về hưu, có lương ổn định. Vợ chồng chị có hai con trai đã trưởng thành, đi làm có thu nhập. Hiện tại, gia đình chị chăn nuôi gà. Nhưng vợ chồng chị vẫn đi làm thuê như phu hồ. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.500.000 vnđ/tháng. Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi.  Bên cạnh đó chị vẫn nhiệt tình tham gia ccong tác nhóm cụm vay vốn và là cụm trưởng cụm vay vốn. Cùng vay với chị còn có: 
 Nguyễn Thị Lượng sinh năm 1952 ,( Mã số: 010103080008 )chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để chăn nuôi lợn, gà. Gia đình có thu nhập ổn định khoảng 2.500.000 vnđ/tháng. 
 Nguiyễn Thị Trọng sinh năm 1977,( Mã số: 010103080009) tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để nấu rượu, nuôi lợn. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.000.000 vnđ/ tháng. 
 Nguyễn Thị Lụt sinh năm 1945,( Mã số: 010103080010), chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 3.270.000 vnđ để nuôi cá. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.000.000 vnđ/tháng.
 Nguyễn Ngọc L. sinh năm 1971,( Mã số: 010103080011). Gia đình chị có cửa hàng bán đồ điện dân dụng . Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư cửa hàng
texts.en:
Mrs. Kieu T. V. (born in 1958 and ID: 010103080006) is a retired worker with a stable income. She has two grown-up children, both of whom have been working for a while. Even though she and her husband are currently raising chickens at home, they still have to go work at the construction sites. The family’s income is about 3500000 VND per month. She would like to borrow 4142000 VND to raise poultry. Her group includes: Mrs. Nguyen T. L. (born in 1952, ID: 010103080008) would like to borrow 4142000 VND to raise chickens and pigs. Her family’s monthly income is 2500000 VND. Mrs. Nguyen T. T. (born in 1977, ID: 010103080009) would like to borrow 4142000 VND to make wine and raise pigs. Her family’s monthly income is about 3000000 VND. Mrs. Nguyen T. L. (born in 1945, ID: 010103080010) would like to borrow 3270000 VND to raise fishes. Her family’s monthly income is 3000000 VND. Mrs. Nguyen Ngoc L. (born in 1971, ID: 010103080011) would like to borrow 4142000 VND to invest in her small shop selling electricity appliances.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: chăn nuôi

loans.name: Mrs. Khoeun Svay Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eight people who all live in Peam Tunlea village in the Kampong Chhnang province make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Khoeun S. is a village bank president who has been selected by the members. The loan will be used by its members for different purposes. For instance, Mrs. Khoeun S. is requesting a loan to buy pesticide to support her bean field since it has been damaged by insects. She hopes to make her crop more productive with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Nhem Chin, helps her on the plantation. Mrs. Khoeun S. is 54 years old and the mother of a child who assists her with the farming.

All members in this village bank loan are end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase pesticides to support her bean field which has been damaged by insects.

loans.name: Sun

texts.en:
Sun P., 46, is a widow with four children. She lives in Kampong Cham, Cambodia.

Sun P. has a business selling fermented fish at the market and earns around US$3 per day. She is also supported by one child who works as a driver. Sun P. has requested a loan to purchase more fermented fish from fishermen to resell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase more fermented fish.

loans.name: Matalena

texts.en:
Matalena L., 37, is married with 4 children. She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the villagers and the public 2 days per week.

Matalena has 3 previous loans with Kiva partner SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 420 Tala (~175 USD). SPBD loans are Matalena’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. With her loan, Matalena will purchase chemicals, pesticides and equipment needed for running and maintaining her plantation business. Part of the loan will also be used to pay her children's school fees

loans.use: Buy chemicals, pesticides and equipment for her plantation

loans.name: Francisco

texts.en: Francisco A. Jr., 40, married with 3 children, and a resident of Tambo, Carmen, Cagayan De Oro City is currently engaged in cement hollow-block making. His business is located in another village which is about 5 kms. from his residence. He started his business with a partner before but unfortunately, the business failed. With his strong desire to revive the business,  Francisco used  his skills, expertise, and effort to make such business back in operation -- this time on his own. He joined the HSPFI microfinance program and was granted a first loan amounting to PHP 5,000 to procure materials needed for hollow-block fabrication. Due to increasing demand for his products, he needs an additional loan of PHP 8,000 loan to purchase sand, gravel and cement in order to make his business more competitive in the market.

loans.use: to purchase sand, gravel and cement for hollow block fabrication

location.town: Scions, Canitoan, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Mrs. Pheakk Kdey Hoem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of nine people and is located in Por village in the Kampong Chhnang province. Mrs. Pheakk Kdey H. is a village bank president. She is a farmer who cultivates both rice and vegetables. On her second plantation, she grows beans but unfortunately she faces an obstacle because her field has been damaged by insects. In order to deal with this problem, Mrs. Pheakk Kdey H. has decided to request a loan to buy pesticides to kill all kinds of insects. She is a 23-year-old widow with a child who is too young to work or study.

All members in this village bank loan are end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase pesticides for her plantation.

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng T., 55, is the mother of two married children. She has a business selling porridge in the Kampong Cham province. On average, she makes around US$8 in revenue per day and her husband earns US$2.50 a day by working as a local teacher. This couple is also supported by their two children who work as farmers.

Mrs. Seng would like to take out a loan of US$700 to purchase more utensils and chairs, in order to increase the amount of porridge she sells.

loans.use: To purchase more utensils and chairs.

loans.name: Hana

texts.en:
Hana E., 28, is married with 2 children. She has 4 years of experience in the business of planting and selling vegetables. She sells to the village people and general public 2 days per week.

Hana has no previous loans with Kiva partner SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (~104 USD). SPBD loans are Hana’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Her loan will focus on her business only. She will purchase seeds for vegetables such as tomatoes, cucumbers, cabbages, and lettuce. She will also buy fertilizer, insect killer, cromozone, and other chemicals, along with some equipment for planting.

loans.use: Purchase vegetable seeds, fertilizers, chemicals, and planting equipment

loans.name: Jorry

texts.en:
Jorry M., 37, is a resident of Sto. Niño Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro City. He is still single and is the breadwinner of the family who takes care of his 80-yr. old mother. In his effort to support himself and his mother, he had to find ways to earn a living and ventured into retailing business. 

For now Jorry needs additional capital for his Sari-sari store (a community variety store) and carenderia (food stall). He needs an amount of PHP 10,000 to purchase additional inventory for his store and kitchenware for his carenderia. He aspires to expand his food stall business and be able to accept catering services in the future.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for sale in his store and kitchenware for his food stall

location.town: Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Sisili

texts.en:
Sisili Y., 49, is married with 5 children. She has 5 years of experience in the fishing business. She sells to the general public and villagers 4 days per week.

Sisili has 6 previous loans with Kiva partner SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 800 Tala (~333 USD). SPBD loans are Sisili’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Sisili plans to use this loan for home improvement.

loans.use: Buy a metal roof, timber, cement, a tent, and nails

loans.name: Nuch

texts.en:
Nuch K. is 29 years old and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. This couple together has two young children, one of whom is in school.

Nuch is a goldsmith and makes about US$5 of profit every day. Her husband is a painter. On average, he makes around US$6 per day. Nuch would like to take out a loan of US$1200 to purchase gold and goldsmithing tools.

loans.use: To purchase gold and goldsmithing tools.

loans.name: Tae

texts.en:
Tae P., 46, is married with 7 children. She has 5 years of experience in the sewing and cattle businesses. She sells to the public 6 days per week. Her husband does all the farming work.

Tae has 4 previous loans with Kiva partner SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD). SPBD loans are Tae’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Part of the loan will be used to purchase equipment for her sewing business and part will be used to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: Purchase equipment for her sewing business

loans.name: Rolly

texts.en: Rolly A., 74 years old, single, lives alone and is striving to earn money for his needs and the needs of his family living in Cebu City in central Philippines. Every 3:00 o’clock early in the morning he goes to the market to purchase goods for his business. He is a concessionaire in a canteen located inside the ISUZU Car Shop. His direct customers are the employees and clients of the shop. The demand of his business is getting bigger that is why he needs financial assistance to expand his operation. He is planning to put up another food vending stall, which he owns, at Abellanosa – Burgos St. With this expansion, he needs an amount of PHP 10,000. He is a new client of HSPFI and this is his first loan. This loan would be a great help since this would primarily increase his income so that he will be able to send his nephews and nieces to school.

loans.use: Build another food stall

location.town: Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Bou

texts.en: Bou M. is 47 years old and lives with her husband (pictured here) in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. They have five children; three are students, and one is a driver. She and her husband are farmers and sell beef at the market to earn approximately $5 profit every day.  Mrs. Bou is asking for a loan so she can purchase more cows to trade.

loans.use: Purchase more cows to trade

loans.name: Mahsad

texts.ru: Махсад, женщина 52лет замужем имеет двоих детей.Уже 15 лет как занимается бизнесом продажи полотенец,покрывал,постельных наборов.По привозке товаров ей помогает её муж.Товар она привозит из Бишкека и Турции.Махсад арендует отдел в престижном магазине города Худжанда.Партнёры по бизнесу посоветовали ей стать кредитором Микроинвест. Т.к.у них благодаря кредитам изменения в бизнесе в увеличительную сторону, то Махсад решила попробовать сотрудничать с нами.
texts.en:
Mahsad B., 52, is married and has 2 children. Mahsad sells towels, blankets, and bedding sets. She has been in business for 15 years. She rents a section of a prestige store in Khudzhand. Mahsad travels to Bishkek and Turkey to purchase her goods. She will use this loan to purchase additional inventory.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase store inventory

loans.name: Soli

texts.en:
Soli S., 56, is married with 8 children. She has 3 years of experience in the pig business. She sells to the public one day per week. She is requesting a loan to purchase a fence for her pig farm.

Soli has one previous loans with Kiva partner SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD). SPBD loans are Soli’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase a fence for her pig farm.

loans.name: Khalida M.imran Group

texts.en:
Khalida imran baji is 21 years old and married. She has resided in the city of Multan, Pakistan for the past 3 years. Her husband, M., has had a scrap business for the past 10 years. Khalida baji helps her husband by doing embroidery on dresses. She is applying for a loan to buy more scrap for his scrap business.

She is a group leader of some more women of her locality. Shamim baji and Najma baji each want a loan to buy scrap for their scrap businesses. Zahida baji wants a loan to buy embroidery material (beads, colored thread and sketches) for her decorative embroidery business. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy cold drinks for her cold drink corner.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy scrap for scrap business

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina F. sells the rice that she grows for additional income. She is 51 years old, and farming is her family's only source of livelihood. The harvest is used for family consumption, and the rest is sold to rice traders in their village. Because of her rice farm business, Josefina was able to send her 3 children to school. The income that she gets from her rice is what she uses to pay the tuition fees as well as her children's other needs.

She is asking for a loan of Php 5,000 from CEVI (Kiva's Field Partner). She will use the loan to buy fertilizers, herbicides and other farm chemicals. She believes that a loan would bring her good harvest. She is also willing to invest in some other business if she has enough capital.

CEVI helps entrepreneurs expand their businesses. Through CEVI credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage, more of its clients succeed in their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, herbicides and other farm chemicals

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira M. is a rice grower. She has 4 children who are still studying. Now that she is 41 and her children need more assistance from her in their studies, she can't avoid worrying about where to get the money to pay all their tuition fees and for school projects. Her husband, Raul M., is helping her sustain their business. Farming is their only source of income, which they inherited from their parents. Together, they work hard to run their farm.

Elvira is asking a CEVI (Kiva's Field Partner) for a loan of Php 5,000. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers for her farm. Specifically, the loan will be used to buy sniper chemicals to improve the yield of her rice crops. She is also looking into some other possible income areas to support her family well.

CEVI is a field partner of KIVA in the Philippines. It provides all its client like Elvira not just credit assistance, but also trainings in their business and insurance coverage to help them grow their businesses more.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and herbicides.

loans.name: Norberto

texts.en:
"I am the father and the provider; I will do my best to support well my family needs," says Norberto L., 49-year-old father of 6 children. "Because of our farm, we earn. Our earnings are what we use to feed our families," he said. "I have been working so many years in the farm. This helped me sustain my family and send all my children to school," he added.

Norberto is requesting a loan from CEVI (Kiva's Field Partner) to grow his farm. He will use the loan to buy complete fertilizers and insecticides to ensure a quality harvest. He thinks that his loan will bring him a higher yield of his crops. In this way, he could support his children's educational needs well.

For 10 years, CEVI has been helping its clients like Norberto grow their businesses. Through credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage, more and more people succeed in their businesses.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for his farm

loans.name: Parveen M. Khalid Group

texts.en:
Parveen baji is 28 years old and married. She has been a citizen of the city of Multan, Pakistan for the past 25 years. She is the mother of one son and one daughter. Both of her kids are in kindergarten.

Parveen baji is a seamstress; she sews clothes to pay the school fees of her children. Her husband, M. K., has been involved in a scrap business for the past 10 years. Parveen baji is applying for a loan to buy scrap for her husband’s scrap business.

Parveen baji is a group leader of some more women of her locality. Kosar baji and Shahnaz baji each want a loan to buy donkey carts for loading.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy scrap

loans.name: Jhomar

texts.en:
Meet Jhomar T.. He grows rice. Everyday he goes out on his farm, touches the loam, wet soil, feels the heat of the sun, and plows the field with his carabou to ensure quality harvest to support his family. He is 19 years old and single. Most of his earnings go to his parents' and siblings' needs.

He is asking for a loan of Php 5,000 from CEVI (Kiva's Field Partner). He will use the loan to buy more fertilizers for his farm. The fertilizers will help a lot to increase his yield. He is hoping that he will have more food to give his family in the coming harvest. His loan will enable him to purchase the needed fertilizers for his crops to increase his harvest.

CEVI is helping people like Jhomar T. grow their businesses. Because CEVI provides their clients credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage, they have created an impact and uplifted people's lives.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and herbicides for his farm

loans.name: Roldan

texts.en:
Roldan C. owns an internet cafe. He is 26 years old and married and has no child. He operates an internet shop in his village. Most of his customers are students who conduct internet research for their school assignments, wives chatting with their spouses working abroad, and children hooked on computer digital games.

He is also a client of CEVI (Kiva's Field Partner). He is requesting an additional loan of Php 5,000 to buy additional computer parts. He is planning to add computers. In this way, he could accommodate more customers in his shop.

CEVI partners with entrepreneurs to grow their businesses. They give all their clients not just credit assistance, but also trainings, savings and insurance coverage services.

loans.use: To buy additional computers

loans.name: You

texts.en: You S. is 28 years old and lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. This couple has two young children. Mrs. You Seanghaiy has been operating a CD shop from her home and earns about $3 profit every day. Her husband (pictured here) has a business making jars and earns $7 per day. Mrs. You Seanghaiy is asking for a loan of $400 to purchase construction materials so her husband can make more jars to sell.

loans.use: Construction materials to make glass jars

loans.name: Phem

texts.en: Phem S., 53, is married and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She works on her rice field and earns approximately $2 per day. Her husband is the local doctor in the village and earns $4 each day Mrs. Phem S. requests a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorbike for commuting to work. The rest of the loan will be used to purchase medicine.

loans.use: Purchase a motorbike for commuting and medicine

loans.name: Happy

texts.en:
Happy has owned a small grocery store in the Tengeru neighborhood of Arusha for 12 years. Every day she works at her business from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $250.

Happy is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more grocery items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business. She belongs to the Uamsho group (group code 2054).

Happy is 33 years old, single, and has two children, aged 13 and 3. She also cares for four additional dependents.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items for her business.

loans.name: Tafuteni Group

texts.en:
Rose has owned a small electronics equipment shop in the Tengeru neighborhood of Arusha for 5 years. Every day she works at her business from 6:30 a.m. to 9:30 p.m. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $225. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more electronics items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Rose is 28 years old and married with two children. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Eliwandesha and Afrasion, who each has her own small business in Arusha.

loans.use: To buy more electonics items for her business.

loans.name: Hun

texts.en:
Hun S., 53, is a widowed farmer who lives with her daughter in the Kampong Cham province in Cambodia. She earns about $3 per day. Her daughter works in a garment factory in Phnom Penh, making about $3 every day, and contributes to the family's income.

To make more money to help support her family, Hun S. has an idea to create another business. She is requesting a loan to purchase a horse and a cart to operate a transportation business.

loans.use: Purchase a horse and a cart to start a transportation service

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard P. owns a studio. He takes professional photos of his clients and is paid for his quality services. He also sells his pictures framed. He earns more income from this portion of the business. That is why he is planning to make his business grow by putting additional capital into it. He is 23 years old and single. Though he is young, he knows how to manage his business well to sustain it. He likes pictures, and his passion to capture every moment led him to open a photography shop. Now, he is not just enjoying his business but his earnings as well.

He is requesting a loan from CEVI (Kiva's Field Partner). He will use the loan to buy more frames for his studio. He has many clients waiting. He needs to increase his capital to accommodate all of them. His loan will help him attract more clients. Quality frames are the most appropriate thing for the quality images that he captures.

CEVI provides their clients an opportunity to start and grow their businesses. They give all their clients credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase frames for his photography studio

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng C., 49, is a professional handicraft maker who lives in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She makes various kinds of baskets and sells them at the market. She earns approximately $3 per day. She and her husband have four children, two of whom are in school. They also have one child who is a barber, and one who is a garment worker.

Her husband stays at home and helps her make baskets. Mrs. Seng C. is asking for a loan from Kiva to purchase more bamboo so she can make more baskets to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase bamboo.

loans.name: Jonie

texts.en:
Jonie E. rents a farm. He grows rice in a 2-hectare lot owned by a barangay councilor in their village. He is 38 years old and has 3 children. His wife, Reginia E., is very supportive of him, especially in taking care of their children. His farm feeds his family. He produces an average of 190 sacks every harvest. He reserves his produce for the family's consumption, and the rest is sold to some rice traders for additional income.

He is asking for a loan from CEVI (Kiva's Field Partner) to increase his yield. He wants to buy more fertilizers and insecticides. The loan will truly help him provide for the needs of his family, especially his children who are studying. When he is not busy on the farm, Jonie also drives "habalhabal,' a kind of transportation which is popular among provinces in the Philippines.

CEVI provides their clients a chance to uplift their lives. Through credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage that they give, most of their clients are able to grow their businesses.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and insecticides

loans.name: Yorn

texts.en: Yorn Y. is 30 years old and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She is a professional hairdresser and makes $5 every day. Her husband grows and sells mushrooms, and earns about $4 per day. This couple has one young child. Yorn is asking for a loan to purchase straw and some materials for growing mushrooms. The rest of the loan will be used to build a small hut to grow the mushrooms.

loans.use: Purchase straw and some materials for growing mushrooms

loans.name: Galilaya Group

texts.en:
Eliashea has owned a small shop in the Tengeru neighborhood of Arusha for 16 years. Every day she works at her business from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m., and she currently earns an average monthly profit of $225. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more commodities for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Eliashea is 50 years old and married. She has four children and also cares for one additional dependent. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Ana, who also has her own small business in Arusha.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for her business.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene has been a vegetable seller in the Tengeru neighborhood of Arusha for 3 years. Every day she works at her business from 8:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $90.

Irene is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more vegetables for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Irene is 26 years old. She is married and has two children. She belongs to the Bahati group (group code 2022).

loans.use: To buy more vegetables for resale

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann M. owns a rice field. She and her husband grow rice to support their family. She is 34 years old and has 4 children. Her life is on the farm, and almost all of their produce is reserved for their family's consumption, while the remainder is sold to the rice traders in their village. Because this is the family's only source of livelihood, Mary Ann wants to expand her farm. By doing so, she believes, she will have more harvest and income for the family.

She is requesting a loan of Php 11,000 to run her farm. She will use the loan to buy sacks of fertilizers and tanks of herbicides and insecticides to increase crop yield. She is also thinking of some other business lines to augment the family's income.

CEVI (Kiva's Field Partner) helps Mary Ann sustain her farm. She is provided with credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage by CEVI to make her business grow.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, insecticides and herbicides for her farm.

loans.name: Akhtari Akbar Ali Group

texts.en:
Akhtari baji is 51 years old and married. She has been a citizen of the city of Arifwala, Paksitan for the past 20 years. Her husband, A. A., is a fruit seller who has 10 years of experience in his profession. Akhtari baji is the mother of three sons. Her eldest son has a flower selling business. Her middle son is a carpenter. Her youngest son reads in 12th standard and wants to be a doctor in future.

Akhtari baji is a very supportive lady. She helps her husband pack the fruits in cartons so that he is able to work more efficiently and deliver the fruits to the shop keepers. She is applying for a loan to expand her husband’s fruit selling business.

Akhtari baji is the group leader of some more women of her locality. Nasreen baji wants a loan to pay the remaining installments for her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Shakeela kosar baji wants a loan to buy fishes for her fish and meat selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Hun Seng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank, which consists of twenty people, is located in Tropang Buon village in the Kampong Chhang province. Mrs. Hun S. is a village bank president who has been selected by the members. All the members will use the loan obtained for different purposes. For instance, Mrs. Hun S. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land and cultivates rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Nort PhS., is a firewood seller. Since Mr PhS.'s business is doing well, he would like to expand so Mrs. Hun S. has decided to ask for a loan to buy more firewood. Mrs. Hun S. is 44 years old and the mother of two children, one of wH. is a farmer while the other is attending the local school.

Fifteen members in this village bank loan are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood for her husband's business.

loans.name: Vasif

texts.en:
Vasif F. is a young, energetic guy who wants to improve his family's living conditions. He is 22 years old and lives in Imishli, Azerbaijan. He has a shop where he sells spare parts for foreign and Russian cars. He has been involved in this business for more than three years; he helped out his father before he opened his own shop. He provides spare parts for cars and provides his family with food and other necessities.

There is a great demand for Vasif's spare parts, so he wants to buy more supplies to meet his clients' demands. He is seeking an individual loan to expand his shop's inventory. He has pledged to repay this loan within 15 months. Vasif is excited about this loan and would like to thank everyone for their trust and support.

loans.use: To buy more spare parts

loans.name: Shamim Shabbir Hussain Group

texts.en:
Shamim baji is a 36 year-old married lady and a citizen of a city named Arifwala, Pakistan for the past 10 years. Her husband's name is S. H. and he runs a butcher shop in a food market. He has been in this business for the past 6 years. Shamim baji is the mother of two kids: one daughter and one son. Both of her kids are getting education from the school located near to the house. Shamim baji shares the financial burden of her husband by sewing clothes for her relatives and neighbors. She does this work to pay off the school fees of her kids. She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy goats to expand her husband’s butcher shop. 

She is a group leader of some more women of her locality. Sakina baji wants a loan to buy repairing tools for her motor workshop. Shamshad baji wants a loan to buy electric items (switches, tube lights) for her electric items workshop. Mumtaz baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy goats for butcher shop

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en:
Teddy has owned a small grocery store in the Tengeru neighborhood of Arusha for 9 years. She belongs to the Utii loan group (group code 2040). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $185. Every day she works at her business from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more grocery items for her business. She is hopping that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to grow her business.  

Teddy is married, and has two children, ages 15 and 10.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items for her business

loans.name: Mrs. Sopheap Hat Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nineteen people, who all live in Tropang Buon village in the Kampong Chhang province, make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Sopheap H. is a village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land and cultivates rice for a living. Her husband, Mr. Noy Soklun, is a palm juice collector who gathers it to process into palm sugar. To make palm sugar, Mr. Noy Soklun needs firewood to burn palm juice into palm sugar. Mrs. Sopheap H. has decided to request a loan to purchase firewood for this purpose. She is 27 years old and the mother of three children two of whom are attending the local school while the youngest one is only three years old.

Thirteen members in this village bank loan are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase firewood to burn palm juice into palm sugar.

loans.name: Phach

texts.en: Mrs. Phach P. is a villager in Ta Kroung village in the Kampong Chhnang province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land and cultivates rice for a living. The plantation provides a small amount of revenue which is not enough to support the family. In order to provide better conditions, Mrs. Phach P. has decided to request a loan to buy another  piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Soeng Chean, is a firewood seller.  Mrs. Phach P. is 38 years old and the mother of three children one of whom is employed in a garment factory, one is attending the local school and the youngest is only five years old.

loans.use: To purchase a piece of land to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Mwanaid

texts.en:
Mwanaid has been a clothing seller in the Tengeru neighborhood of Arusha for 1 year. She belongs to the Upendo loan group (Group code 2001). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $25. Every day she works at her business from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes for her business. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.  

Mwanaid is single.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Mrs. Khen An Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loA., which consists of eleven people, is located in Peam Tonlea village in the Kampong Chhnang province. Mrs. Khen A. is a village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a farmer who cultivates both rice and vegetables. In her second plantation, she grows beans; unfortunately, she now faces a problem because her crop has been damaged by insects. To deal with this problem, she has decided to request a loA. to buy pesticides to kill all kinds of insects and she hopes to make her crop more productive. Her husband, Mr. Real Kon, helps her on the plantation. Mrs. Khen A. is 60 years old and the mother of two children one of whom helps her while the other is attending the local school.

All members in this village bank loA. are end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loA. until the very end of the loA. term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loA. term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase pesticides to kill all kinds of insects on the plantation.

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en:
Hadija has owned a small hotel (restaurant) in the Tengeru neighborhood of Arusha for one year. She belongs to the Kibisote loan group (Group code 2007). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $50. Every day she works at her business from 6:30 a.m. to 10:30 p.m. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more commodities for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to grow her business.  

Hadija is 36 years old, married, and has 8 children.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for her business.

loans.name: Shahnaz M. Yaqoob Group
loans.use: To buy materials for her beauty parlor.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean S. grows rice on her farm. Her parents taught her everything about farming, from planting the seeds to harvesting. Now that she has her own family, she wants to increase her yield with the help of her husband, Dindo S., to support her 3 children well. Their harvest is used for the family's consumption. The rest is sold to their neighbors and other villagers who want to buy newly-harvested rice.

Jean is asking a loan from CEVI (Kiva's Field Partner) to improve her farm. She will use the loan to buy sacks of fertilizers and tanks of pesticides to increase her crop's yield. She believes that her loan will bring her good harvest. When that happens, she will have more to give to her children.

Jean is one of the thousands of entrepreneurs and clients of CEVI. By joining in the CEVI credit program, all are provided with credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, insecticides and seeds.

loans.name: Janali

texts.en:
Janali A.  is 21 years old. He is single and lives with his parents. Janali is a market vendor. He sells women’s clothes in the local market of Imishli city. In 2006 Janali took a loan from AqroInvest and could start his business. Over two years of working at the market, Janali already has got enough experience to do his work successfully and has customers who always come to him.

Janali is trying to satisfy the needs of all his customers with various tastes and income levels. Today Janali is planning to increase his working capital in order to purchase new goods to sell. With this purpose in mind, he is requesting $1200 for a term of 15 months. Janali has successful loan history and this time promises to repay the loan promptly and thanks all supporting him. Your generosity can change their lives. Be an important part of the growth of Janali’s business!

loans.use: Purchase new goods to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy sacks of corn and millet that she uses to prepare the meals that she sells.

loans.name: Mr. Tol Nhieb Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of ten people, is located Chrolorng village in the Kampong Chhnang province. Mr. Tol N. is a village bank president who has been selected by the members. He is a farmer who grows lotus in his lake. His plantation now faces a problem because he does not have enough money to buy more lotuses to grow in the lake. Thus, he has decided to request a loan for this purpose. His wife, Mrs. Min Lao, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land and cultivates rice to earn a living. Mr. Tol N. is 29 years old and the father of two children who are too young to work or study because they are only three and four years old. All the members are presented in the picture but one is blocked.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Six members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more lotuses to grow in the lake.

loans.name: Mrs. Sok Ny Tum Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank, which consists of ten members, is located in Prey Khmer village in the Kampong Chhnang province. The loan which they obtain will be used for different purposes. Mrs. Sok Ny T. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She sells clothing in the local market. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more clothes to resell and earn more profits. Her husband, Mr. U. Kea, is a jeweler. Mrs. Sok Ny T. is 35 years old and the mother of three children who are all attending the local school.

Six members in this group have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to resell.

loans.name: Aiza

texts.en:
"I am a mother who dreamed big for my family. I wanted my children to graduate in college so that later on when they are older, they could find better job and support better their future families," says Aiza S.. She is 20 years old and has only 1 child. She lives in Bunawan Agusan Del Sur, a town of 32,233 people and 5,372 households. They are known for rice. This is their primary source of livelihood.

Aiza started her rice farm business in 2008. With her husband's help, she was able to save money from their harvest. She is asking for another loan from CEVI (Kiva's Field Partner). She will use the loan to buy fertilizers for her farm. Her loan will greatly help her increase their yield. This will also help her to start another line of business.

"CEVI provides me not just credit assistance that I need, they also give me trainings and insurance coverage while I am still a member of their credit program," she said.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Iltifat

texts.en:
Iltifat S. is 55 years old and is married with three children. He is a small entrepreneur who sells different kinds of foodstuffs such as: cookies, candies, soft drinks, juices, tea and many others in his grocery store which he built five years ago. Currently, Iltifat has about US$ 1500 of goods in his inventory. His monthly net profit is about US$ 150-200. 

Today, Iltifat is requesting a loan of 1200 USD for a term of 14 months to increase his stock. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once in a while to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. One of his dreams is that his children will progress in their studies. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.

loans.use: Purchase food products for re-sale

loans.name: Ngô Thị Hằng Group

texts.vi:
Chị H., 27 tuổi là một phụ nữ trẻ khéo léo, đảm đang, tháo vát. Hiện nay chị đang sống cùng chồng, bố mẹ chồng và 2 con nhỏ. Chị là một thợ may, ngoài thời gian làm nghề chị còn cùng chồng cấy lúa,trồng H. màu, chăn nuôi gà, lợn. Chu kỳ trước, gia đình chị đã vay vốn để chồng chị đi buôn trứng gà. Việc kinh doanh khá tốt nên gia đình chị không chỉ hoàn trả vốn vay rất tốt mà còn thu về khoản tiền lãi khá lớn để tiếp tục phát triển chăn nuôi. Thu nhập gia đình chị khoảng 150.000-200.000 vnđ/ ngày. Chu kỳ này chị tiếp tục vay 4.256.000 vnđ/ 12tháng/ chu kỳ 2 để mua thêm lợn giống và thức ăn chăn nuôi. Các thành viên còn của nhóm chị là :
  Cô Nguyễn Thị
texts.en:
Mrs. Hang, aged 27, is very energetic and skillful. She is currently living with her husband, parents-in-law and her two young children. Besides being a tailor, she is a farmer and is currently raising poultry at home. In the previous round, she asked for a loan to buy and sell chickens’ eggs, from which she has been able to earn enough to pay back the loan and save for the future. Her family’s income is about 150.000-200.000 VND per day. In this round, she would like to borrow 4.256.000 VND to buy two pigs and food for the poultry. Other members in her group include: Mrs. Nguyen Thi Uoc, aged 53, would like to borrow 4.256.000 VND to buy pigs and invest in her small shop. Mrs. Nguyen Thi M., aged 33, would like to borrow 4.256.000 VND to buy pigs. Mrs. Nguyen Thi H., aged 28, would like to borrow 4.704.000 VND to buy pigs and ingredients to make vermicelli. Mrs. Nguyen Thi Chin, aged 26, would like to borrow 4.256.000 VND to buy and sell fruits and make wood-things to sell.

Translated from Vietnamese by KH. Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Nhóm chị Hằng vay vốn để mua giống chăn nuôi và bổ sung vốn để phát triển buôn bán nhỏ, làm nghề.

loans.name: Mrs. Vanna Soeurn Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twelve people living in Prey Khmer village in the Kampong Chhnang province comprise this village bank loan. The loan will be used for various purpose. Mrs. Vanna S., a pig breeder, is the 44-year-old village bank president. Since her business is doing well, she would like to expand it and has decided to ask for a loan to buy two more piglets for breeding to earn more income. Her husband, Mr. Nuo Pin, is a farmer who owns a plot of land and cultivates rice. Mrs. Vanna S. has three children, two of whom are enrolled in the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study. Mrs. Chheng Chhun who is a group guarantee is presented in the picture with the village bank members.

Ten members in this group loans are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase two more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Chuon

texts.en: Chuon S. is 25 years old and lives in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Chuon has a motorbike and trailer and every day he transports wood to earn a living. He is able to make $4 profit per day. His wife stays at home cooking food and looking after their young child. She also has a business raising pigs on a plot of land behind their house. On average, she earns $1 each day. Mr. Chuon is asking for a loan to purchase a motorbike and trailer to start a transportation business.

loans.use: Purchase a motorbike and trailer to start a transportation business

loans.name: Yasmeen M.shafiq Group
loans.use: To buy dry fruits to sell.

loans.name: Khuseyn

texts.en:
Khuseyn M. is married with three children. This is an average family from Imishli, Azerbaijan. However, Khuseyn is a unique entrepreneur. Together with his wife, he has been selling women's clothes in the central city market for about 7 years. The secret of his success is simple: he tries to not only let their customers know the benefits of their products, he also gives them a sense of belonging which brings them back again and again.

However, Khuseyn doesn’t want to stop where he is with his venture. Khuseyn is seeking a loan of 1200 USD to replenish the merchandise in his store. We believe that Khuseyn’s desire to excel by pleasing his customers will determine his further success and encourage new customers to buy from him.

loans.use: Purchase women's clothing

loans.name: Mẫn Thị Hòa Group

texts.vi:
Chị Mẫn Thị H. năm nay 44 tuổi chị đăng ký vay mức 4.704.000VNđ để mua gỗ đóng giường, tủ, bàn ghế. Hiện tại chị giúp con trong việc làm bóng, đánh giấy giáp, cho những bộ bàn ghế mà gia đình chị làm để bán. Hàng ngày chồng chị đi làm thợ xây và một con chị đi làm công nhân nên mức thu nhập của gia đình chị cũng ngày càng ổn định hơn, đồng thời có thêm thu nhập để hoàn trả vốn. Chị rất thích tham gia hình thức vay trả này, vì nhờ có hình thức vay trả và tiết kiệm mà gia đình chị có kế hoạch trong việc chi tiêu. Chị cùng nhóm đã tham gia qua một chu kỳ và hoàn trả rất tốt, nên chu kỳ này chị và nhóm sẽ đăng ký và vay tiếp sang chu kỳ II.
 Trong nhóm chị có các thành viên như sau:
  Anh Nguyễn V. T. năm nay 46 tuổi, anh đăng ký vay mức 5.152.000VNđ để đi chợ mua thóc về xát gạo bán.
 Chị Nguyễn Thị M. năm nay 50 tuổi chị đăng ký vay mức 4.704.000VNđ để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn, vịt.
 Chị Mẫn Thị Luyến năm nay 29 tuổi chị vay mức 4.704.000VNđ để đầu tư vào việc bán hàng ăn sáng.
texts.en:
Mrs. Man Thi Hoa, aged 44, would like to borrow 4.704.000 VND to buy wood to make beds, desks, and chairs. She is currently helping her son in polishing the furniture. Her husband is a construction worker and her other child is a blue-collar worker. The family’s income, as a result, has become much more stable. Mrs. Hoa is very interested in borrowing loan and paying it back in a certain period of time because it has helped her better manage the family’s finances. She and other members in her group have fully paid back the loans in the first round. In the next round of loan, other members in her group include: Mr. Nguyen Van Tai, aged 46, would like to borrow 5.152.000 VND to make and sell rice. Mrs. Nguyen Thi M., aged 50, would like to borrow 4.704.000 VND to raise poultry. Mrs. Man Thi Luyen, aged 29, would like to borrow 4.704.000 VND to make and serve breakfasts for customers.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: vay vốn kinh doanh

loans.name: Mrs. Yat Prak Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Thirteen people living in Prey Khmer village in the Kampong Chhnang province comprise this village bank loan. The loan will be used for various purpose. Mrs. Yat P., a grocer with a small store, is a 58-year-old village bank president. She is a widow with two children who work in different positions. Even though Mrs. Yat P.’s family members have different careers, they still cannot provide a better house for their family. Thus, Mrs. Yat P. has decided to request a loan to add to her savings to build a better house for her family.

Five members in this group loan are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To add to her savings to build a better house for her family.

loans.name: Hoeung

texts.en: Hoeung K. is 38 years old and lives with her sister in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her sister have a business selling sugar cane juice, cages, and vegetables, and are able to make around $5 every day. Hoeung K. requests a loan to purchase a motorbike for her transportation. This will help her save money on transportation costs.

loans.use: Purchase a motorbike

location.town: Tboung Kmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambo

loans.name: Sean

texts.en: Sean S. is 24 years old and runs a hair-dressing shop from her home. She lives in Kampong Cham with her husband. On average, she makes about $8 per day. Her husband makes $3 each day by selling rubber. Mrs. Sean is asking for a loan to purchase a small truck to transport rubber for her husband's business.

loans.use: Purchase small truck to transport rubber

location.town: Tboung Kmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambo

loans.name: Chhean

texts.en: Chhean S., 47, sells vegetables in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. On average, she makes $4 per day. Her husband earns about $5 by running a motor-taxi around the market. Two of their children are mechanics at a garage. Mrs. Chhean is requesting a loan to purchase car-painting tools.

loans.use: Purchase car-painting tools

location.town: Tboung Kmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambo

loans.name: Lubna Liaquat Ali Group

texts.en:
Lubna baji, 36, a resident of Arifwala, Pakistan, is married to L. A., a jewelry seller for the past decade. The mother of three daughters, all attending school, Lubna baji operates a sewing business in order to pay for their school fees. She is now applying for a loan to expand her husband’s jewelry business.

Lubna is a group leader of two other women in her community: Rukhsana baji wants a loan to buy goats for her butcher shop; Nasreen baji is requesting a loan to buy fish for her fish-selling business.

The funds for this group loan will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members guarantee one another's loans, so if one does not repay, the others are responsible.

loans.use: To buy jewelry to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To build a house for her family

loans.name: Him

texts.en: Him N., 61, lives with her husband in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She sells vegetables in the market and makes about $10 profit per day. She has one child who works as mechanic in a local garage and receives $250 per month. To make more money, Mrs. Him would like to create another business by purchasing rice in bulk and reselling it when the price is high.

loans.use: To purchase and resell rice

location.town: Tboung Kmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambo

loans.name: Mẫn Thị Thanh Group

texts.vi:
Chị Mẫn Thị T. năm nay 47 tuổi chị đăng ký vay mức 2.912.000VNđ để bổ sung thêm nguồn vốn của gia đình và mua gỗ về sản xuất bàn ghế để B.n. Hàng ngày chị cùng 2 con sản xuất bàn ghế B.n ra thị trường, còn chồng chị hàng ngày đi làm thợ xây dựng và chăn nuôi lợn, vì vậy thu nhập của gia đình chị cũng bớt đi những khó khăn mà bấy lâu nay gia đình chị đã gặp phải. Đồng thời gia đình chị lại được vay vốn trả góp, mà không phải trả một gánh nặng trong cùng một lúc, nên chị thấy phù hợp và thuận tiện với gia đình chị. Chu kỳ II này chị cùng nhóm đăng ký vay tiếp với các thành viên trong nhóm như sau: 
 Chị Trương Thị H. năm nay 54 tuổi vay mức 4.704.000VNđ để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi gà đẻ, lợn.
 Chị Nguyễn Thị N. năm nay 27 tuổi vay mức 4.704.000VNđ để chăn nuôi lợn.
 Chị Nguyễn Thị
texts.en:
Mrs. Man Thi T., aged 47, would like to borrow 2.912.000 VND to purchase more wood to make desks and chairs to sell. She and her two children make home furniture from wood everyday and sell it to the market. Her husband is a construction worker and also raises pigs at home. The family’s income as a result has been improved a lot. Mrs. T. is very interested in borrowing loans and paying them back in a certain period of time because this method is suitable for the family’s business. Other members in her group include: - Mrs. Truong Thi Hoat, aged 54, would like to borrow 4.704.000 VND to raise poultry. - Mrs. Nguyen Thi N., aged 27, would like to borrow 4.704.000 VND to raise pigs. - Mrs. Nguyen Thi Dan, aged 34, would like to borrow 4.704.000 VND to invest in her small shop. - Mr. Man Ba Nguyet, aged 56, would like to borrow 4.704.000 VND to raise poultry.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vay vốn  kinh doanh và chăn nuôi

loans.name: Shalale

texts.en:
Shalale T. is 45 years old and lives with her spouse and two adorable sons. Shalale works every day, starting very early in the morning, so that she can get ahead and achieve her goal of having her two children successfully finish school and enter University.

Shaleale sells women's clothes in the central market of Imishli town. Thanks to the support of her spouse, and her own effort, she has been able to expand and grow her business. With this loan of 1200 USD, which she will repay in 15 months, she will buy a greater variety of clothing styles for a variety of occasions, and a few specific requests from her customers.

loans.use: Purchase women's clothes

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas T. is 55 years old and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She sells used clothes at the market and earns approximately $10 each day. Her husband is a construction foreman. He has been in business for 10 years and makes $20 per day. This couple has two children. Mrs. Meas requests a loan of $1000 to purchase more construction tools for her husband.

loans.use: Construction tools

location.town: Tboung Kmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambo

loans.name: Mrs. Nhoeum Kong Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eleven people living in Prey Khmer village in Kampong Chhnang province comprise this village bank loan group. The members will use the loan for various purposes. 

Mrs. Nhoeum K. is the 46-year-old village bank president. She is a grocer. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy a more groceries for her business so she can earn more income. Mrs. Nhoeum K. is a widow with two children. One child is employed in a garment factory. The other is a construction worker. 

Ten members in this group have end-of-term (EoT) loans; the rest have monthly payment loans. The members with EoT loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a more groceries

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock her store

loans.name: Chorn

texts.en:
Chorn S. is 40 years old and lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She grows and sells rice from her rice field and earns around $3 per day. Her husband catches fish in the lake and sells the fish in the market. He makes $4 every day. This couple has three children; two are in school and one is a farmer.

Chorn S. has a new idea to make additional income to help support her family. She requests a loan to purchase a car for her husband to start a taxi business.

loans.use: Purchase a car to start a taxi business

location.town: Tboung Kmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambo

loans.name: Khon

texts.en: Khon S., 29, is married and lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She sells coffins. Her husband is a goldsmith at the local market and earns approximately $10 every day. She and her husband have one young child. Mrs. Khon Sokhheng requests a loan of $800 to purchase a small truck to transport coffins.

loans.use: Purchase a small truck to transport coffins

location.town: Tboung Kmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambo

loans.name: Mema Group

texts.en:
Mkema J., age 47, is married with three children ages 17, 12 and 2.  He sells new clothes. He started this business in 2000 and works daily from 8am until 8pm. He is able to earn a monthly profit of around $40. 

This will be Mkema's sixth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans to increase his stock of clothes and has repaid the loans successfully. He hopes this loan will increase the size of his business again.
	
Mkema will share this loan with his loan group, Mema, which totals 16 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable to pay back their loans. In the picture, Mkema is 1st on the left in front.

loans.use: Increase clothing business

loans.name: Panakh

texts.en:
Panakh A. is 47 years old. He works as a merchant in a rented store where he sells children's toys. Panakh  started his business 9 years ago. He is married and has six children. As it is very hard to cover all the needs of such a big family, Panakh tries very hard. His business is the main source of income for the family. 

Panakh is trying to have a wide range of goods with good quality to meet the requirements of his customers and to satisfy the needs of customers with different levels of income. Today, Panakh is requesting a loan of 1200 USD for a term of 14 months. This is the first time that Panakh has asked for a loan through AqroInvest and KIVA. It will be used to buy more toys in order to increase the range of his goods. Panakh and his family are counting on your help.

loans.use: Purchase toys for re-sale

loans.name: Saida

texts.ru:
Файзуллоева Саида 1979 года рождения, она за мужем и у нее 1 ребенок. Начала свой бизнес с продажи детской одежды. У нее 9 лет опыта в предпринимательской деятельности. Она торгует на рынке "Станция" города Вахдат. У нее широкий ассортимент детской обуви и одежды для детей до школьного возраста. Это сапоги, ботинки, туфли, комплект одежды для младенца, джемпера, носки, спортивная одежда. Покупает свой товар на оптовом рынке Корвон.
Саида хочет получить с помощью программы Кива займ в сумме 2000 сомони, чтоб закупить детские спортивные обуви.
texts.en:
Saida F. was born in 1979, she is married with one child. She started her own business selling children's clothing. She has nine years of experience in this field. She sells on the market Station in the town of Vahdat. She has a wide variety of children's clothing and shoes for preschool children. The items include boots, different types of shoes, clothing sets for toddlers, jumpers, socks, and sports wear. She buys her merchandise on the wholesale market Korvon. Saida wants to get a loan with the help of Kiva for 2000 somoni (US$550) to buy children's sports shoes.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy children's sports shoes

loans.name: Nuru-Kimanga Group

texts.en:
Fatuma N., age 37, is married with two children ages 15 and 18. She also cares for two dependents – orphans age 14 and 11. Fatuma has a salon business. She has had the business for  7 years and works daily from 8am until 8pm. She is able to earn a monthly profit of around $150.

This will be Fatuma’s 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She hopes the loan will improve her salon business.
	
Fatuma will share this loan with her loan group, Nuru, which totals 19 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable to pay back their loans. In the picture, Fatuma is standing 1st on the right in a black dress.

loans.use: Improve her Salon.

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en: Vivian A. is a 36-year-old mother of 5 children who are in school. She is very hardworking and resourceful for her family. She trades in charcoal in her neighborhood. Charcoal is a very popular source of energy for cooking in almost all Ghanaian traditional homes. Vivian obtains her supply of charcoal from Afram, where she lives, and retails it to her customers. She wants to use the loan to buy bulk supplies of charcoal to increase her inventory. She hopes the loan will enable her to increase her savings to pay her children’s educational fees, as that has been her priority. She belongs to the village bank called Choice.

loans.use: To buy bulk supplies of charcoal

loans.name: Khanlar

texts.en:
Khanlar K. is 48 years old. He is married with two adorable daughters. He is a small entrepreneur who sells various souvenirs in his store. His store is very famous in his community thus allowing him to have a good clientele. 

Currently, Khanlar has about 800 USD in inventory and his monthly net profit is about US$ 100-120. Today Khanlar is requesting a loan of 1200 USD for a term of 14 months to increase his stock. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once in a while to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. 

Khanlar’s main goal is to educate his beloved daughters so that someday they’ll become successful entrepreneurs. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will be key success factors in his small business.

loans.use: Purchase various souvenirs for his store

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is already a widow and a mother of five children: Sherly – 39 years old, college graduate and now working in the municipality of Tumauini, Isabela; Alex – 37 years old, college graduate and engaged in farming as his business; Rovilyn – 35 years old, also a college graduate and working in Manila; Mildred – 33 years old, college under graduate and Elmer – 30 years old, is a high school graduate. Two of them failed to finish their college degree due to early marriage.  Gloria was thankful for having her good children and able to keep her family strong and happy.  They are living in the peaceful village of San Vicente Tumauini, Isabela together with some of her grandchildren.
 
Gloria chooses a village store as her business for almost two years.  She wanted to further improve her business and for this she is asking for a loan of PHP 7,000.  This amount will be of great help in improving her store so that she could support her needs without depending too much on her children, now that she is getting old.  Gloria is looking forward to develop a good working relationship with the lenders  and for her business to grow and for her to become a successful businesswoman someday so she can also help her children and grandchildren.

loans.use: Store Improvement

loans.name: Isidro

texts.en:
At the age of 53, Isidro is still very determined to provide a better life for his family. He is married to Vilma who is seven years younger. They live in Baranagay (township) Magassi of Cabagan, Isbela, located along the national highway going north toward Tuguegarao City. They have five children of whom four are currently studying in the tertiary level in Isabela State University at Cabagan campus. Their youngest child is now in fourth year high school. Isidro admitted that he is having some difficulties in sending his children to school but he is doing his best for them to finish their studies.

In order to maintain his hog-raising business, Isidro is asking for a loan of PHP 5, 000. The said loan will also assist him in maintaining his farm lot that serves as their source of income. Isidro is working hard in order to fulfill his dreams for his family and overcome every struggle that comes up.

loans.use: Farm maintenance and hog-raising capital

loans.name: Harakati Group

texts.en:
Adam R., age 35, is married with three children ages 2, 8 and 12. He sells second-hand clothes at the Karuma market. He started this business in 1998 and works daily from 6am until 6pm. He is able to earn a monthly profit of around $104. 

This will be Adam’s 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He wants to increase his capital so that he can get a larger stock of clothes for his business.
	
Adam will share this loan with his loan group, Harakati, which totals 15 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable to pay back their loans. In the picture, Adam is in the middle wearing a grey shirt.

loans.use: To buy more clothing

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
In the village of Pilitan in Tumauini, Isabela, lives a micro-entrepreneur named Lilian C.. She believes that “if there’s a will, there’s a way”; this is her reason why her family is happy despite the obstacles they have encountered. She is already 40 years old and married to William, a farmer. They have three children: Judith, Mark, and the youngest is Willboy. All of them are in high school level. Lilian and her husband are sacrificing a lot to send them to school with the hope that they can have a better life in the future.

Lilian is operating a simple village store. Her products include: snacks, crackers, and ice candies. Her request is for a loan of PHP 4,000 which will be used to purchase additional merchandise for her store. She also plans to buy soft drinks and some native delicacies as snacks that she will sell. Lilian is looking forward to the success of her business and hoping that she can maintain it for their family's sake.

loans.use: Purchase of additional merchandise

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel is a young mother to three children: Jocel, 5 years old; Mark Jay, 3 years old; and Joy, 1 year old. Their family is living in the village of Antagan, 1st Tumauini, Isabela. Maricel is married to Joel, a farmer. Their place is quite developed and there is sufficient supply of water for their rice fields coming from the Pinacanauan River.

Maricel is a vegetable vendor. She used to roam around the village selling her products, but her income is not enough to support the needs of their family. Because of this, she would like to borrow a loan of 5,000 pesos to expand her vending business. She is hoping that lenders will grant her request, for this will be of great help not only for her business but also to her family.

Maricel believes that hard work and endurance are the formulas in reaching for success. She also dreams to send all her children to school someday.

loans.use: Expand her vegetable sales.

loans.name: Alla

texts.en:
Alla is married with three children. She rents a space in a department store and sells gifts and decoration items. She has been in this business for six years and knows the business well. She tries to offer her clients interesting and nice products that can satisfy their demands. Alla enjoys this gift business because "gifts soften people's hearts".

Alla would like to receive a loan of 8,000 grivnas to increase the assortment of her goods. She will spend the additional profit to take care of her children. She believes that God can help her to develop this business even further.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of goods she sells.

loans.name: Remigia

texts.en:
