Se dedica a la venta de artículos de uso medico como jeringas, guantes quirúrgicos, fármacos, etc. Tiene este negocio de manera independiente desde hace 11 años  y sus ventas las realiza acudiendo ella misma a ofrecer estos productos a hospitales, farmacias, consultorios médicos, etc. vende al por mayor, su gran meta es ser una de las abastecedoras de estos artículos médicos a todos los establecimientos de salud posibles y es por ello que su trabajo lo realiza todo el día, de lunes a viernes y descansa los fines de semana. Como una mujer de negocios y a la vez madre de familia ella no descuida la atención de sus hijos, es por ello que distribuye su horario para no descuidar su hogar. Hasta el momento Ana manifiesta que es un negocio rentable y una buena fuente de ingresos, además es muy cuidadosa de comprar sus artículos de laboratorios oficialmente establecidos y confiables. Es la cuarta vez que Ana está solicitando un préstamo en MFP, ella es una de  las integrantes de su banco comunal que ha perseverado en un trabajo en equipo y la que siempre promueve la responsabilidad  en su grupo, ya que para ella trabajar en equipo es lo más gratificante. El dinero que está solicitando es para adquirir 3 cajas de jeringas, guantes  y medicamentos. Ella invertirá el monto total que solicita en estos tres artículos principales de su mercadería.
texts.en:
Ana is 48-years old and lives with her husband in their own house. They have two children. She sells medical supplies such as syringes, medical gloves, pharmaceuticals, etc. She has independently run this business for 11 years, personally going to hospitals, pharmacies, and medical clinics to sell her products. Her goal is to be the main medical supplier to as many health facilities as possible. Ana sells wholesale, working Monday through Friday and only resting on weekends. As both a businesswoman and a mother, she never neglects her children, scheduling her work so that she can also take care of her family. Until now Ana's business has proven to be profitable and a good source of income. She is also careful about buying her supplies from established, reliable laboratories. This is the fourth loan that Ana has requested from MFP. In her community bank she is one of the members who most enjoys working with others and encourages the responsibility of the group. Her loan request is for the purchase of three boxes of syringes, medical gloves, and medicines. She will invest the entire loan in these items for her inventory.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing merchandise

loans.name: Obdulia Mercedes

texts.es:
Obdulia  inicio el negocio porque necesitaba un ingreso para poder darle un mejor futuro a su hijo 
Comenzó en el año 1998,  ella era empleada de una maquiladora y al ser despedida comenzó a hacer trabajos de costura en su casa, ya que ella vio que con esta actividad tenia la posibilidad de ganar suficiente dinero para mantener a su familia, debido a  que ella es madre soltera y tenia deseos de poder darle la oportunidad de estudiar a su hijo del cual ella esta muy orgullosa
   
Cuando comenzó su negocio solo reparaba ropa a los vecinos y en la actualidad ya elabora uniformes y distintas prendas de vestir y ya cuenta con una maquina de coser industrial, lo que le ha permitido alcanzar un mayor progreso. 

Ella necesita un prestamo por MXN $5,000 que pagara en 24 semanas para  comprar material de trabajo, podra  adquirir mas hilo y  telas para poder aumentar su producción y así sus ganancias
texts.en:
Obdulia started her business because she wanted to provide a better future for her son. It began in 1998 when she lost her job at an assembly plant and began to take on sewing work from home. She saw the possibility of earning enough money to support her family with this work. As a single mother Obdulia wanted to give her son, of whom she is very proud, the opportunity to study. When she began her business she only made clothing repairs for her neighbors but now she also makes uniforms and different types of clothes. She has an industrial sewing machine that allows her to take on more work. Obdulia needs a loan of 5,000 MXN, to be repaid in 24 weeks, to buy work supplies, thread, and cloth to increase her production and thus her income.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase work supplies

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es:
La señora Gloria es socia del Banco Comunal “03 de Mayo”, en el centro poblado Pueblo Libre, distrito de Ilave, Provincia de El Collao, Departamento de Puno; tiene 35 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, tiene 04 hijos y posee estudios de secundaría incompleta (segundo grado). 
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 06 años, se dedica a la comercialización de frutas (manzanas, uvas, plátanos, etc.); su primer préstamo fue de S/ 300.00 nuevos soles, con lo cual pudo adquirir mercadería para su negocio según la época (sandia, uvas, etc.) 
Con este préstamo de S/ 3000.00 nuevos soles, monto que se compromete a pagar en 5 cuotas, podrá adquirir mas mercadería (frutas) para su negocio según la demanda y la época, tales como: Sandía, plátanos, Papayas, uvas, etc., con las ganancias ella piensa ayudar en la educación de sus hijos; asimismo su sueño es tener su auto propio (camioneta) para llevar sus productos a otras ferias de la región.
texts.en:
Gloria is a member of the community bank "03 de Mayo," in the El Collao province of Puno. She is 35 years old, and lives with her four children and their father. She has achieved a second-grade level education.

She has worked with Manuela Ramos (a Kiva partner) for 6 years, and she sells fruit (apples, grapes, bananas, etc.). Her first loan was for 300 Peruvian Soles, with which she was able to acquire merchandise for her business, depending on the season (watermelon, grapes, etc.). With this loan of 3000 Peruvian Soles, which she hopes to repay in 5 installments, she will be able to buy more merchandise (seasonal fruit) for her business such as: watermelon, bananas, papayas, grapes, etc.

With the earnings, she hopes to help with her children's education, and her dream is to have her own vehicle (a truck) to bring her products to other fairs in the region.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase additional merchandise (fruit)

loans.name: Juan Sergio

texts.es:
Juan inició el negocio por superación económica y personal, para tener un negocio propio y  también tener mayor ingreso para la manutención de su familia. 
comenzó el negocio? (Fechas) En Marzo de 1998

Un amigo lo invitó a iniciar el negocio de venta de material para soldadura, luego el se independizó cuando tenía suficientes conocimientos del mismo.
Comenzó el negocio en Marzo de 1998, debido a su esfuerzo ha ido progresando  gradualmente conforme a la situación económica y a la afluencia de la clientela, pero el crecimiento se ha debido más al cumplimiento de los trabajos encomendados, ya que se hacen en el tiempo en el que se lo solicitan.

Ahora necesita un préstamo por MXN $6,000 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar más material para que el negocio sea mucho más productivo, y tener con que financiar sus compromisos en lo que le hacen los pagos.
texts.en:
Juan started the business to improve his personal and financial situations, as well as to generate more income to support his family. It began in March of 1998, when a friend invited him to start an enterprise selling soldering materials. Later, after learning enough about the business, he set off on his own. Thanks to his hard work and efforts, he has grown gradually, along with his economic situation and flow of customers. The growth has occurred, in large part, because of the completion of work orders, which he makes sure are delivered on time. He currently needs a loan of 6,000 MXN, to be repaid in six months, to buy more materials so the business will be more productive. Also, it will help him finance his orders.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase materials for his work.

loans.name: Libertad Group

texts.en:
The Libertad (Freedom) Bank of Hope from San Pedro de Macoris is starting their first loan with Esperanza International. These 15 women are very enthusiastic to receive this opportunity and have great plans for their now small businesses.

Jeantilia J. is the coordinator for Group 1. She is married and has two grown children. She owns a colmado, which is a small food market where you can buy different types of groceries. She states that the products with more demand are rice, beans, oil, and canned goods, so she will use her loan money to purchase a quantity to cover her customers' demands. Rice and beans are part of the typical Dominican lunch fare. If it is under the family's financial possibilities, rice and beans are usually served with meat.

Other businesses that the group members have include clothing sales and fried food stands. Thank you for supporting these entrepreneurs!

loans.use: To purchase a variety of merchandise

loans.name: Rosa Margarita

texts.es:
La señora Rosa es socia del Banco Comunal “03 de Mayo”, en el centro Santa Barbara, distrito de Ilave, Provincia de El Collao, en el departamento de Puno; tiene 42 años de edad, es madre soltera y tiene 02 hijos a su cuidado, posee estudios de secundaria completa. 

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 05 años, posee un negocio de tienda de abarrotes; su primer préstamo fue de S/ 300.00 nuevos soles, con el cual pudo adquirir mercadería para su negocio. 

Con este préstamo de S/ 3000.00 nuevos soles el mismo que lo pagará en 05 cuotas mensuales; dicho préstamo le servirá para poder incrementar mercadería en su negocio y de esta manera incrementar la capacidad de su tienda, es decir comprar más azúcar, arroz, golosina, bebidas, etc. Todo al por mayor; con ello piensa obtener mejores ganancias las que piensa invertir aún más en su negocio (su sueño es tener una bodega propia y una tienda de artefactos) con la ayuda de sus hijos. 
 
Ella agradece de sobremanera a Manuela Ramos por su apoyo a las mujeres.
texts.en:
Rosa is a member of the communal bank "03 de Mayo," in the El Collao district of Puno. She is a 42 years old single mother of two children, and she has completed her secondary level of education.

She has worked with Manuela Ramos (a Kiva partner) for 5 years, and she sells groceries. Her first loan was for 300 Peruvian Soles, with which she bought merchandise for her store. With this loan of 3000 Peruvian Soles, which she will repay in 5 monthly installments, she will be able to increase her merchandise and so increase the capacity of her store. That is, she will buy more sugar, rice, sweets, drinks, etc., all wholesale.

With this, she hopes to secure higher earnings which she can reinvest in her business (her dream is to have her own store and a store of artifacts) with the help of her children. Rosa is very grateful to Manuela Ramos for her support of women.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her grocery store

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.es:
La señora Rosalía es socia del Banco Comunal “Ciudad Blanca” centro poblado de Chijichaya, distrito de Ilave, Provincia Del Collao, Departamento de Puno; tiene 29 años de edad, de estado civil casada, tiene 01 hijos a su cargo y posee estudios de secundaria completa. 
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 03 meses, posee un negocio de compra y venta de productos de la región (papa, chuño, cebada, quinua, etc.); su primer préstamo fue de S/ 500.00 nuevos soles, con lo cual pudo adquirir mas  mercadería  de la zona los que lo vende en las ferias de Puno y Arequipa. 
Con este préstamo de S/ 500.00 nuevos soles, monto que se compromete a pagar en 3 cuotas mensuales; podrá mantener su mercadería adquiriendo mas papas, chuño, cebada, maíz, habas, etc. Para poder venderlo en las ferias de Puno y Arequipa; uno de sus anhelos es convertirse en mayorista y llevar sus productos a los mercados mayoristas de Lima; asimismo ella desea comprarse una casa en Arequipa para su familia, por ello viene ahorrando con gran esmero.
texts.en:
Rosalía is a member of the community bank “Ciudad Blanca” located in the Collao province in Puno. She is 29 years old, married with one child, and has completed her secondary education.

She has worked with Manuela Ramos (a Kiva partner) for 3 months. She buys and sells products local to the region (potatoes, barley, quinoa, etc.). Her first loan was for 500 Peruvian Soles, with which she bought more merchandise from the fairs in Puno and Arequipa. With this new loan of 500 Peruvian Soles, which she hopes to repay in 3 monthly installments, she will maintain her inventory, purchasing more potatoes, dried potatoes, barley, corn, beans, etc. and will sell them in the fairs at Puno and Arequipa.

One of her goals is to become a wholesaler and to bring to her products to the wholesale markets in Lima. She also would like to buy a home in Arequipa for her family, and for this goal she is carefully saving her money.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of additional inventory to sell in the fairs in Puno and Arequipa

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.es:
Alejandra inició el negocio   Porque cuando vivía su esposo a veces no le iba muy bien en su trabajo y ella quiso ayudarlo con los gastos de la casa y después, cuando el falleció, gracias al negocio pudo subsistir y sacar adelante a sus hijos. Comenzó el negocio  en Marzo de 1985 todavía vivía su esposo, el trabajaba como empleado y ella atendía la tienda y como su casa quedaba en una calle muy transitada, acondicionaron el patio de su casa y puso un local de madera pequeño. Empezó con un local pequeñito, pero gracias a su crédito anterior con Kiva pudo ampliar y acondicionar mejor su local y ahora cuenta con mayor espacio

Ella necesita un préstamo por MXN $8,000 que pagara en 12 catorcenas  para comprar más abarrotes que le permita tener mejor surtida su tienda y dar un mejor servicio a sus clientes
texts.en:
Alejandra started her business because when she lived with her husband sometimes things did not go well at his work and she wanted to help him with the household expenses and later when he died she was able to survive and take care of her children thanks to the business. She opened her business in March 1985 when her husband was still alive. He was employed elsewhere and she took care of the store and since her home was on a very busy street, they installed air conditioning to the patio and set up a small wood store. She started with a tiny store but thanks to previous loans from Kiva she was able to expand and better air condition her store and today has a larger space. She needs a loan of MXN $8,000 which she will repay in 12 installments to buy more groceries which will allow her to be better stocked and give her customers better service.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Nimia

texts.es:
La señora Nimia es socia del Banco Comunal “Ciudad Blanca”, Santa Rosa,  centro poblado de Chijichaya, distrito de Ilave, Provincia Del Collao, Departamento de Puno; tiene 25 años de edad, de estado civil casada, tiene 01 hijos a su cargo y posee estudios de secundaria completa. 
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 06 meses, su negocio es la elaboración de tunta (chuño blanco) y compra y venta de quinua; su primer préstamo fue de S/ 500.00 nuevos soles, con lo cual pudo adquirir papas para procesar en chuño blanco. 
Con este préstamo de S/ 900.00 nuevos soles, monto que se compromete a pagar en 03 cuotas mensuales; podrá adquirir productos de la zona (papa, chuño blanco, quinua, etc.) para verlos en Arequipa, asimismo desea comprarse un par de animales menores (chanchos) para engordalos y venderlo en la época de carnavales; con las ganancias ella desea ahorrar y juntar capital a fin de ampliar su negocio; asimismo se preocupa por la educación y sustento de su hijo.
texts.en:
Nimia is a member of the community bank “Ciudad Blanca” in the Collao province of Puno. She is 25 years old, married with one child and has completed her secondary education.

She has worked with Manueal Ramos (a Kiva partner) for 6 months. Nimia makes tunta (a product derived from dried white potatoes) and buys and sells quinoa. Her first loan was for 500 Peruvian Soles, which she used to buy potatoes to make the dried potato product.

With this new loan of 900 Peruvian Soles, which she hopes to repay in 3 monthly installments, she will buy local products (potatoes and dried potatoes, quinoa, etc.) to sell in Arequipa. She would also like to buy some small animals (pigs) to fatten them up and sell them during the carnival season.

With these earnings, she would like to save up to grow her business as well as take care of the education and support of her son.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy local products like potatoes and quinoa and to purchase pigs

loans.name: Martha

texts.es: Martha tiene 41 años, vive  con su esposo y sus hijos en una casa que se encarga de cuidar. Desde hace más de 5 años se dedica a ofrecer el servicio de lavado de ropa, ella y su esposo son las principales fuentes de ingresos en su hogar y es por ello que Martha  eligió esta actividad. Lava diariamente las prendas de vestir de sus vecinos y con ello  cada semana obtiene ingresos, cobra 3 soles la docena de prendas simples y las más gruesas y difíciles de lavar hasta 15 soles. El tiempo y el esfuerzo en su trabajo ocasionan en Martha constantes resfríos por lo que quiere comprase una lavadora que le ayude con su trabajo, porque hasta el momento lava todo a mano. Este es su segundo préstamo con MFP, ella es una de las socias más activas de su banco comunal y de las más responsables, y siempre pide un crédito de acuerdo a sus posibilidades. Con la cantidad solicitada, logrará por fin, comprar una lavadora doméstica de 15 litros de capacidad en lavado, esto facilitara en gran medida el trabajo que realiza.
texts.en:
Martha is 41-years old and lives with her husband and children in the house where she is caretaker. For more than five years she has provided laundry services. Martha and her husband are the family's main providers, which is why she chose to work. Everyday she washes her neighbors' clothes, charging 3 PEN per dozen garments, and up to 15 PEN for heavier garments that are more difficult to wash. The time and effort required to wash clothes by hand causes Martha to catch colds easily, and she wishes to buy a washing machine to help her in her work. This is her second loan from MFP. Martha is one of the most active and responsible members of her community bank. She always requests a loan amount within her capacity to repay. With the amount she is currently requesting she will finally be able to buy a 15-liter capacity washing machine, which will make her work much easier.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of washing machine

loans.name: Cosme

texts.es:
Cosme trabajo en varias empresas, en todas ellas por contrato fijo y nunca hizo
Atigüedad, además fue chofer de transporte público por su cuenta y nunca se jubilo o pensiono, por lo que inicio su propio negocio para salir adelante. Comenzó el negocio n Febrero de 2006 Primero vendiendo joyería ya que su esposa se dedicaba a esto y veía que le iba bien, pero como algunos clientes le quedaron a deber decidió cambiar al giro de compra-venta de ropa nueva y siente que le ha ido mejor en esta actividad. Aunque tiene poco dedicándose a vender la ropa le ha ido bien y ya cuenta con un buen número de clientes que compran sus productos.

El solicita un préstamo por MXN $3,000 que pagara en 6 catorcenas para comprar mas mercancía y poder tener un mejor surtido de ropa que pueda ofrecer a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Cosme worked for a number of businesses. All his jobs were on contract and he never had job seniority. He also was self-employed working as a public transportation driver and he never retired: he started his own business in order to better his situation. He opened a jewelry business in February 2006 as his wife had the same type of business and he saw it was going well, but because some clients did not pay him he decided to change businesses and began buying and selling new clothing and feels this business is better. Although he has not been selling clothing for very long, the business is going well and he has a good number of customers who buy his products. He is asking for a MXN $3,000 loan which he will repay in 6 bi-weekly installments to buy more merchandise and increase the stock of clothing to offer his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise for his clothing business

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
El negocio de Margarita lo inició el negocio su esposo era vendedor de los dulces antes de casarse y después decidió ella elaborar el dulce por que con solo la venta le daban muy poca ganancia, así que desde que se caso aprendió a elaborar los dulces de leche. Comenzó en el año 1991 los papas de su esposo son los que originalmente elaboraban ese producto, y ellos les ensañaron a elabóralos.

Desde el año 1991 se independizaron de la familia, puesto que era un negocio familiar; para tener mayores ingresos y no depender de un salario que les proporcionaban sus suegros. Anteriormente solo ellos eran los únicos trabajadores, elaboraban, vendían, todo lo hacían ellos solos pero con el paso de los años pusieron vendedores en la orilla de la carretera Nacional para aumentar sus ganancias, además de contratar a una persona para que le ayudara a la Sra. Margarita a elaborar el producto y así fue que poco a poco fueron creciendo.

Ella necesita ahora de un préstamo por MXN $3500 que pagara en 12 catorecnas para comprar materia prima como por ejemplo: leche de cabra, nuez, azúcar, etc. Y poder continuar con su negocio.
texts.en:
Margarita started her business because her husband sold desserts before they married and later she decided to make them herself because sales alone did not generate much profit. And so, since getting married she has learned to make "dulce de leche", a milk-based dessert. She started this business in 1991; originally it was her husband's parents who made the desserts and they are the ones who taught her. Since 1991 they have become independent from the family business and have started their own store in order to make more profits and not be dependent on a salary given them by her in-laws. Previously they alone were the workers: they prepared as well as sold the desserts. With time, they have hired salespeople to sell at the edge of the highway to make greater profits and have also hired someone to help Margarita prepare the desserts. Over time the business has grown. Margarita now needs a loan of MXN $3,500 which she will repay in 12 bi-weekly installments to buy ingredients such as goat's milk, walnuts, sugar and so on, and to continue to build her business.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her desserts

loans.name: Karen Soledad

texts.es:
La señora Karen es socia del Banco Comunal “03 de Mayo”, en el distrito de Ilave, Provincia de El Collao, en el departamento de Puno; tiene 31 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, tiene 02 hijos a su cuidado, posee estudios de superior completa (enfermería técnica).
 
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 01 año, posee un negocio de tienda de abarrotes; su primer préstamo fue de S/ 500.00 nuevos soles, con lo cual pudo adquirir mercadería para su negocio (gaseosas). 

Con este préstamo de S/ 1500.00 nuevos soles, el que pagará en 05 cuotas mensuales; le servirá para poder incrementar la capacidad de su tienda, es decir comprar más azúcar, arroz, golosina, leche, fideos, bebidas, etc. Todo al por mayor; con ello piensa obtener mejores ganancias las que piensa ahorrar para poder comprarse una casa en la ciudad de Ilave o Moquegua para sus hijos. 
 
Ella agradece de sobremanera a Manuela Ramos por su apoyo a las mujeres.
texts.en:
Mrs. Karen is a member of the “03 de Mayo” Community Bank in the Ilave District of the Collao Province in the Puno Region. She is 31 years old and lives with her two children and their father. She has completed a degree in higher education (vocational nursing).

She has worked with the Manuela Ramos Movement for 1 year. She has a grocery store. Her first loan was for 500.00 nuevos soles with which she was able to buy stock for her store (soda).

She will payback this loan of 1500.00 nuevo soles in 5 monthly installments. It will help her to increase the capacity of her store, meaning buy more sugar, rice, candy, milk, pasta, drinks, etc. all wholesale. She hopes to make a better profit, which she plans on saving to buy a house for her children in the city of Ilave or Moquegua.

She is extremely grateful to Manuela Ramos for her support of women.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase goods such as: sugar, rice, candy, milk, pasta, drinks, etc. all wholesale and improve her profits to save for buying a house for her children in Ilave or Moquegua.

loans.name: Chaska Group

texts.es:
Este banco se denomina "CHASKA", nombre en quechua, idioma original de los Inkas, que significa "Estrella"; Este banco está ubicado en el distrito de Wanchaq de la cuidad del Cusco, cuenta con 11 miembros entre los cuales se tiene a 09 mujeres y 02 varones, Todos ellos con muchas ganas de hacer sus propios negocios y así contrubuir a sus hogares.

Estos socios, desean invertir el préstamo otorgado, en diferentes negocios, 04 socias invertirán en la apertura de un restaurant de comida típica, otras 02 socias en un cafetín y comida rápida, otras 02 socios en la compra de artesanía al por mayor y revender a tiendas minoristas, 01 socia invertirá el préstamo en la compra de 02 licuadoras para su pequeño negocio de juguería en el mercado central, 01 socia para la garantía de alquiler de su nuevo negocio (snack café), 01 socia desea ivertir el dinero prestado en el pago de sus estudios en un instituto de turismo, ella trabaja también medio tiempo, pero el pago de sus mensualidades no le espera a que en su trabajo le paguen.

Los socios agradecen y valoran mucho el apoyo y la ayuda brindada, ya que en otras instituiones de banca financiera, los trámites son muy engorrosos; ellos harán buen uso de ese préstamo y se comprometen a pagar lo solicitado en el plazo determinado.
texts.en:
This bank is called “CHASKA” which means “Star” in quechua, the original language of the Inkas. This bank is located in the Wanchaq district of the city of Cusco. It has 11 members, 9 women and 2 men. All are very much looking forward to starting their own businesses and contributing to their households.

These members wish to invest the loan money in different businesses. Four women will invest in opening a restaurant of local food, 2 other women in a small café and fast food and 2 men in the purchase of crafts wholesale to resell to retail stores. One woman will invest the loan in the purchase of 2 blenders for her small juice-drinks business at the central market, 1 woman to guarantee rent for her new business (snack café) and 1 woman wishes to invest the loan money to pay for her studies at a tourism school. She works part time but her monthly payments are due before they pay her at work.

The members are grateful for and value the support and the help offered since the paperwork at other financial institutions is very bothersome. They will make good use of this loan and they promise to pay it on time.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients and spices to make foods and purchase material for crafts.

loans.name: Hermila

texts.es:
Hermila inició el negocio por ayudar a su esposo con los gastos familiares. Comenzó el negocio en el año de 1998 platicando con su esposo decidieron comenzar a vender dulces y refrescos y les dio resultado, fueron invirtiendo en otros productos haciendo cada vez mas grande su tiendita y su negocio ha ido progresando bien ya que la gente de  su localidad acude a su negocio teniendo buenas ganancias y así reinvierte y va  aumentando su inventario de mercancías.  Lo que le ayuda es que no tiene competencia cerca por lo que goza de buena afluencia de clientes.

Ella necesita un préstamo por MXN $6,000 que pagara en 12 catorcenas para comprar mercancía y continuar exitosamente su negocio.
texts.en:
Hermila started her business to help her husband with the household expenses. She opened in 1998 when after chatting with her husband they decided to begin selling candies and refreshments. The business was successful and they invested in other products, each time enlarging her little store and her business has continued to do well as her neighbours come to her store to buy. The store has generated good profits and so she has reinvested them and continues to increase her inventory. Their greatest asset is that there is no competition nearby and so they enjoy a good influx of customers. She needs a MXN $6,000 loan which she will repay in 12 bi-weekly installments to buy merchandise and successfully continue her business.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Beatriz Maria

texts.es:
Beatriz inició el negocio porque le gustan las ventas, siempre ha sido comerciante desde antes de casarse, y decidió seguir vendiendo para tener un ingreso extra antes de casarse, y decidió seguir vendiendo para tener un ingreso extra. Comenzó el negocio en forma en enero del 2000 ya que una hermana les vendía ropa, empezó con poca inversión, y vendiéndoles a sus vecinas y familiares, también a las maestras de la escuela de sus hijos, y poco a poco fue haciéndose de más clientes.
Gracias a que su negocio ha progresado con parte de la ganancia que tenía, ahora compra el triple de ropa y también empezó el negocio de hacer collares y aretes de cristal para expandir un poco su giro.

Ella necesita un préstamo por MXN $4,000 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar mercancía, con tu apoyo Beatriz continuara con su negocio.
texts.en:
Beatriz started her business because she likes sales. She has been a retailer, even before she got married. Before getting married, she sold goods in order to have extra income. She started forming her business in January of 2000, her sister was already selling clothes at this time. She started with a small investment, and she sold to her neighbors, friends and her children's school teachers. Little by little she gained more clients.

Thankfully, her business has made progress with the earnings that is has, now she is buying triple the amount of clothes and she also started a business making necklaces and crystal earrings in order to expand her business a little.

She needs a loan of MXN $4,000 (Mexican pesos) that she will pay in 6 months. The loan will be used to buy merchandise. With your help Beatriz will continue her business.

Translated from Spanish by Caitlin Brooks, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
La señora Carmen es socia del Banco Comunal “Ciudad Blanca” centro poblado D. Chijichalla, distrito D. Ilave, Provincia Del Collao, Departamento D. Puno; tiene 51 años D. edad, D. estado civil casada, tiene 05 hijos y posee estudios D. primaria incompleta (primero D. primaria). 
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 04  meses, su negocio es la transformación D. la papa en chuño negro  o tunta, además ella  compra y venD.  productos D. la zona (chuño negro, tunta cebada, quinua, etc.); su primer préstamo fue D. S/ 500.00 nuevos soles, con lo cual pudo adquirir mas  mercadería  D. la zona los que lo venD. en las ferias D. Arequipa. 
Con este préstamo D. S/ 900.00 nuevos soles, monto que se compromete a pagar en 3 cuotas mensuales; podrá aumentar capital y adquirir  mas mercadería (mas chuño, papa, cebada, etc.) su anhelo es convertirse en mayorista D. los productos que venD..
Ella agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por su apoyo.
texts.en:
Mrs. Carmen is a member of the “Ciudad Blanca” Community Bank in the town of Chijichalla, Ilave District of the Collao Province in the Puno Region. She is 51 years old and married with 5 children. She didn’t complete her primary education (first graD.).

She has worked with the Manuela Ramos Movement for 4 months. Her business is making dried potatoes called "chuño negro" or "tunta" from potatoes. She also buys and sells products from the area (“chuño negro” and “tunta” dried potatoes, barley, quinoa, etc.). Her first loan was for 500.00 nuevos soles that she used to buy goods from the area, those sold in Arequipa.

She promises to payback this loan of 900.00 nuevos soles in 3 monthly installments. She can increase her capital and buy more goods (more “chuño” dried potato, potato, barley, etc.). She is eager to become a wholesaler of the products she sells.

She is grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for their support.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more goods ("chuno" dried potato, potato, barley, etc.) and increase her own capital. She is eager to become a wholesaler of the products she sells.

loans.name: Israel

texts.es:
Israel inició el negocio ya que siempre le ha gustado la carpintería por que sus hermanos mayores se dedican a este negocio y ellos le enseñaron este oficio y cuando ya tenia algo de experiencia puso su propia carpintería. Comenzó el negocio en abril de  1987 al principio batallo ya que no tenia la herramienta suficiente solamente tenia una cierra de banco, trompo de banco, cepillo de mano y era poca herramienta en general.  Hoy en día cuenta con su camioneta, casa propia y un terreno además de mobiliario completo para su negocio ya que cuenta con todo tipo de herramientas que necesita para elaborar todo tipo de mueble de madera: cocinas, recamaras, puertas principales y reparaciones.

Ahora el necesita de un presta o por MXN $7000 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar madera, triplay, pintura y pegamento; que requiere para su negocio. Con tua apoyo Israel seguirá adelante.
texts.en:
Israel started his business because he has always like carpentry. He was trained by his brothers, who are also carpenters, and once he had some experience he started his own workshop in April 1987. At first he struggled because he didn't have many tools, only a bench saw, table-top wood router (for shaping wood), and a woodworking plane (flat-bladed hand tool for shaping and smoothing wood). Today he has his own truck, house, and land as well as complete furnishings for his work. He has the tools he needs to make all types of wooden furniture: kitchen and bedroom furniture, front doors and repairs. Israel now needs a loan of 7,000 MXN, to be repaid in 6 months, to buy wood, 3-layered plywood, paint and glue that he needs for his work. With your help, Israel can advance his business.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase work materials

loans.name: Cristo Viene 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Groups 1 and 2 from the Cristo Viene (Christ is Coming) Bank of Hope are receiving their fourth loan from Esperanza International. This group has shown good discipline in repayments and their businesses have improved since their first loan.

Altagracia F. is Coordinator for Group 2. She is married and has 3 children, ages 14, 6 and 2. She sells both new and used clothes, mostly around her neighborhood. She will use her loan money to purchase new clothing items to be able to provide variety and meet her customers' demands.

Altagracia has some technical education, but she dreams of seeing her children go to college and become successful professionals. She is very concerned about making her business do well in order to support her children's present and future education. She also dreams of her business growing to become a clothing store in her own locality.

On behalf of Esperanza International, thank you for supporting these entrepreneurs!

loans.use: Purchasing clothes for sales business.

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es:
La señora Antonia es socia del Banco Comunal “03 D. Mayo”, centro poblado Mariategui, distrito D. Ilave, Provincia D. El Collao, Departamento D. Puno; tiene 56 años D. edad, D. estado civil casada, tiene 03 hijos y no posee estudios. 
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 08 años, se dedica a la compra y venta D. productos D. la zona (papa, chuño, quinua, cebada, etc.) y posee una tienda D. abarrotes; su primer préstamo fue D. S/ 300.00 nuevos soles, con lo cual pudo adquirir mas mercadería (productos D. la zona) para venderlo en las ferias locales D. Ilave. 
Con este préstamo D. S/ 3000.00 nuevos soles, que será pagado0 en 5 cuotas mensuales; con lo cual podrá adquirir más mercadería para su tienda D. abarrotes, tales como: leche, arroz, azúcar, aceite, bebidas, etc., con lo cual piensa surtir su tienda; con sus ganancias ella desea incrementar sus negocio D. abarrotes y convertirlo en una bodega granD., ello le permitirá brindar una mejor ayuda a sus hijos en su educación y una fuente D. ingreso económico cuando ella sea D. mayor edad.
texts.en:
Antonia is a member of the Community bank “3 D. Mayo.” She lives in the Mariategui area of the Ilave district in El Collao province in Puno, Peru. She is 56, married, has three children and did not finish school. She has worked with the Manuela Ramos movement for 8 years. She buys and sells regional food products like potatoes, chuño (a type of dried potato), quinoa, and barley. She also has a small grocery store. Her first loan was for 300 nuevo soles which she used to buy more regional products to sell in the local markets in Ilave. With this loan for 3,000 nuevo soles, which she will repay in 5 monthly payments, she will buy more merchandise for her grocery store, like: milk, rice, sugar, oil, drinks, etc. She wants to offer more variety at her store—with her earnings she would like to expand her business and converter her small market into a large grocery store. This would help her proviD. a better education for her children and proviD. income for her once she reaches a more advanced age.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: expand merchandise in her grocery store/market

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: rent a store and stock it

loans.name: Paulina

texts.es:
Paulina E. quiere hacer un baño nuevo, el que tiene ya esta muy deteriorado y en tiempo de frió es muy helado ya que esta hecho de cartón y lamina. Aparte esta en el exterior y  cuando se traslada del baño a su casa a salir  de ahí recién bañada teme a enfermarse ella y su niño o agarrar alguna infección en el estado que se encuentra.
El nuevo baño lo quiere construir dentro de su casa para no exponerse algún problema respiratorio con esta temporada.
Ella percibe ingreso de un negocio de abarrotes  el cual le va muy bien.
texts.en:
Paulina E. wants to build a new bathroom. The one she has is very deteriorated and during the winter it is freezing as it is made of tin and carton. In addition, it is located outside and when she has to go from the bathroom to her house after taking a shower she is afraid she or her child will get sick or get some kind of infection. Paulina wants to build her new bathroom inside her home so that she is not exposed to a respiratory problem during this season. Paulina counts on income from a grocery store that does very well.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials to build a new bathroom.

loans.name: Graciela

texts.es:
La señora Graciela es socia del Banco Comunal “03 de Mayo”, en el centro poblado Porvenir - MiraF., distrito de Ilave, Provincia de El Collao, Departamento de Puno; tiene 54 años de edad, es madre soltera con 04 hijos a su cargo y posee estudios de secundaria incompleta (primer grado). 
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 05 años, ella posee una tienda de abarrotes; su primer préstamo fue de S/ 300.00 nuevos soles, con lo cual pudo adquirir mercadería para surtir su tienda y mejorar su negocio. 
Con este préstamo de S/ 500.00 nuevos soles, monto que se compromete a pagar en 5 cuotas mensuales; podrá adquirir mercadería al por mayor, tales como: arroz, azúcar, leche. Aceite, etc. y de esta manera surtir aun mas su negocio. Su anhelo es construir su casa en la ciudad de Ilave, puesto que cuenta con terreno disponible, por ello viene ahorrando su dinero, con ello garantizará el futuro de sus hijos.

loans.use: Comprar mercadería al por mayor, tales como: arroz, azúcar, leche, aceite.etc. Su anhelo es construir su casa en la ciudad de Ilave, puesto que cuenta con terreno disponible, por ello viene ahorrando su dinero, con ello garantizará el futuro de sus hijos.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.es:
La señora Patricia es socia del Banco Comunal “03 de Mayo”, centro poblado Ramón Castilla, distrito de Ilave, Provincia de El Collao, Departamento de Puno; tiene 33 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, tiene 02 hijos y posee estudios de primaria incompleta (tercer grado). 
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 03 años, se dedica al engorde de ganado menor (ovejas y porcinos), artesanías y venta de comidas; su primer préstamo fue de S/ 300.00 nuevos soles, con lo cual pudo adquirir mas ganado para engordarlo y venderlo como carne en las ferias locales de Ilave y para su negocio de comidas. 
Con este préstamo de S/ 3000.00 nuevos soles, monto que se compromete a pagar en 5 cuotas mensuales; podrá adquirir ganado mayor (03 toros) para engórdalos y venderlos a un mejor precio, con lo cual obtendrá buenas ganancias y podrá mejorar su negocio de venta de comidas; asimismo, su anhelo es construir un Hotel en la ciudad de Ilave, puesto que ya cuenta con el terreno, por ello viene ahorrando sus dinero con gran esmero, con ello garantizará los ingresos económicos de sus hijos para el futuro.
texts.en:
Patricia is a member of the “3 de Mayo” community bank, located in the Ramon Castilla area of the Ilave district, in the El Collao province of Puno, Peru. She is 33 years old and lives with her common law husband. She has 2 children and has a third grade education. She has worked with the Manuela Ramos movement for 3 years. She works raising sheep and pigs as well as selling food and handicrafts. Her first loan for 300 nuevo soles was used to purchase more animals to “fatten them up” and sell them for meat in the markets of Ilave and to use for the food she prepares. With this loan for 3,000 nuevo soles, which she is committed to paying in 5 months, she will buy larger animals (3 bulls) to raise and sell for a good price. With the extra money she will earn, she will work to improve her food-selling business. However, her dream is to build a hotel in the city of Ilave. She already has the land and is saving up her money with great care, in order to guarantee an income for her children in the future.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase 3 bulls

loans.name: Gifty

texts.en:
Gifty A. is 51 years old and a married mother of five children. Her children are currently in school. She lives with her husband and family in Accra. Gifty is very hard working, lovely and very supportive to her family.

Gifty sells fresh fish and supplies to local restaurant operators in her community and use the proceeds to support her family. Gifty started this business about three years ago. She says demand for fish is very high even though Accra is very close to the sea. However, she does not have the capital to meet the demand. She wants to use this loan to buy more cartons of fresh fish to expand her business so she can earn enough income to support her children's education. She belongs to a village bank called Fervent.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of fresh fish

loans.name: Florentino I Group

texts.en:
The Group 1 from the Florentino Bank of Hope in Los Alcarrizos is on their third loan cycle with Esperanza International. Los Alcarrizos is a large district on the northwestern outskirts of Santo Domingo. Many of its habitants are Haitian inmigrants.

Suze C. is one of the group members. Suze is 31 years old, is married and has 2 children. She sells seasoning and cooking spices in her small business at home. All the other group members are involved in clothing sales. Suze's customers are mostly from her own neighborhood. She will use this loan to buy some more products to continue her activities. Her pastimes include reading the Bible, praying, and thinking about new ways to "spice up" her business. She also dreams of providing her children a good education.

On behalf of Esperanza International, thank you for supporting this group!

loans.use: To purchase new merchandise for her business

loans.name: Roxana

texts.es:
La señora Roxana es socia del Banco Comunal “Ciudad Blanca”, centro poblado de Chijichaya, distrito de Ilave, Provincia Del Collao, Departamento de Puno; tiene 24 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, tiene 02 hijos a su cargo y posee estudios de secundaria completa. 
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 06 meses, ella se dedica al engorde de ganado menor (ovejas y chanchos); su primer préstamo fue de S/ 500.00 nuevos soles, con lo cual pudo adquirir mas ganado (ovejas) las que vendió en forma de carne en las ferias de Ilave. 
Con este préstamo de S/ 900.00 nuevos soles, monto que se compromete a pagar en 3 cuotas mensuales; podrá adquirir ganado mayor(un toro) para engordarlo y venderlo a un mejor precio en las ferias de Ilave o Pilcuyo; con las ganancias obtenidas ahorrara y juntara capital para adquirir mas ganado, en el futuro ella quiere comprarse una casa para su hijo y su familia, así como contribuir en la educación y sustento de su hijo.
texts.en:
Roxana is a member of the community bank Ciudad Blanca, in the town of Chijichaya, Ilave district, Collao province, department of Puno. She is 24 years old, married, has two children, and a high school education. She has been working with the Manuela Ramos Movement for six months. Roxana raises livestock (sheep and pigs), and used her first loan of 500 soles to purchase more sheep, which she sold for meat at the fairs in Ilave. With a new loan of 900 soles, which Roxana plans to repay in three monthly instalments, she can purchase a bull to raise. Later, she will be able sell the bull for a good price at a fair in Ilave or Pilcuyo. With those profits, she plans to buy more livestock, eventually buy a house for her family, and put money toward her son's education and well-being.

Translated from Spanish by Corinne Gilroy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cattle (a bull) to raise and later sell at market for a better price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: refurbish his garage and buy tools

loans.name: Katia

texts.es:
La señorita Katia es socia del Banco Comunal “Ciudad Blanca” centro poblado de Chijichaya, distrito de Ilave, Provincia Del Collao, Departamento de Puno; tiene 18 años de edad, de estado civil soltera, no tiene hijos a su cargo y posee estudios de secundaria completa. 
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 06  meses, su negocio es el engorde de ganado menor; su primer préstamo fue de S/ 500.00 nuevos soles, con lo cual pudo adquirir mas ganado (ovejas) para su engorde y venta de carne en los mercados locales. 
Con este préstamo de S/ 900.00 nuevos soles, monto que decidió pagar en 03 cuotas mensuales; podrá adquirir mas ganado, en este caso toros para engorde y algunos animales menores (ovejas), los mismos que engordará y venderá en las ferias y mercados locales de Ilave; con las  ganancias ella piensa seguir sus estudios superiores y apoyar en el sustento de su familia.
texts.en:
Katia is a member of the community bank Ciudad Blanca, in the town of Chijichaya, Ilave district, Collao province, department of Puno. She is 18 years old, single, has no children, and has completed her high school education. She has been working with the Manuela Ramos Movement for six months. Katia is in the business of raising cattle, and with her first loan of 500 soles, she was able to purchase more livestock (sheep) to raise and later sell for meat at local markets. With a new loan of 900 soles, which Katia plans to repay in three monthly instalments, she'll be able to buy more livestock such as bulls and sheep, which she can also sell for meat at local markets in Ilave. With the money she makes, Katia plans to pursue higher education and help support her family.

Translated from Spanish by Corinne Gilroy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase livestock to raise and later sell at market for a better price.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.es:
La señora Virginia es socia del Banco Comunal “Ciudad Blanca” centro poblado de Chijichaya, distrito de Ilave, Provincia Del Collao, Departamento de Puno; tiene 25 años de edad, de estado civil casada, tiene 01 hijos a su cargo y posee estudios de secundaria completa. 
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 06 meses, su negocio es el engorde de animales  menores (ovejas) y a la elaboración de tunta; su primer préstamo fue de S/ 500.00 nuevos soles, con lo cual pudo adquirir ganado (ovejas y corderos) para engordarlos y venderlos en forma de carne en las ferias locales de Ilave. 
Con este préstamo de S/ 900.00 nuevos soles, monto que se compromete a pagar en 03 cuotas mensuales; podrá adquirir papas para trasformarlo en Tunta (chuño blanco) y comercializarlo en las ferias locales de Ilave y Puno; con las ganancias ella desea mantener una adecuada salud, alimentación y educación de su hijo y ayudar en el sustento de su hogar.
texts.en:
Virginia is a member of the community bank Ciudad Blanca, in the town of Chijichaya, Ilave district, Collao province, department of Puno. She is 25 years old, married, has one child, and has a high school education. Virginia has been working with the Manuela Ramos Movement for six month, and she’s in the business of raising livestock (sheep) and preparing tunta (dried white potatoes). With her first loan of 500 soles, she was able to purchase more livestock (sheep and lams) to raise and sell at fairs in Ilave. With a new loan of 900 soles, which Virginia will repay in three monthly instalments, she’ll be able to purchase more potatoes for making tunta (also called chuño), and sell those at fairs in Ilave and Puno. The money Virginia makes will go toward her son’s health, nutrition and education, and will also help her with household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Corinne Gilroy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase potatos for making tunta, which can be sold at market.

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
For past four years, Georgina has been trading in palm oil. She is 49 years old and married with six children. Currently four of them are in the junior high school.

Georgina has been a local manufacturer of palm oil and palm kernel oil for eight years now. Palm oil is produced from palm nuts, while palm kernel oil is produced from palm kernel. The palm kernel is a byproduct of palm oil. The palm kernel is processed through various stages to obtain the palm kernel oil, which is used to prepare many local dishes.

Georgina treks to Twifo Praso, a town in the Eastern region of Ghana to purchase palm nut fruits. She supplies the oil she produces to food vendors to prepare their meals. She normally switches her production between the two products. That is, after producing palm oil, she automatically obtains the raw material to produce palm kernel oil.

She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of palm nuts and an electric milling machine to increase her efficiency so she can produce oil in larger quantities. She believes this will help her expand her business and earn more income to support her family and finance her children’s education. Georgina belongs to a village bank called "Yayra," which means "blessing."

loans.use: To buy more bags of palm nuts and an electric milling machine

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy Yomekpe is 33 years old and is a married woman with two children. One of her children is in school whilst the last born is still breastfeeding. Mercy has been selling frozen foods like chicken, pork, mutton, fish, etc. in the local market of Accra for six years. She does not have adequate funds to support her business. Meanwhile, demand for her product is on the higher side. This has affected her operation, especially in the face of increasing food prices.

With the loan, she wants to purchase more cartons of frozen foods like fish, chicken, pork, and sausages to enable her to raise enough income to expand her sales. She belongs to a village bank called "Yayra" which means Blessing. She hopes to receive GHS 500 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more cartons of frozen foods like fish, chicken, pork, sausages, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase motor oil for re-sale

loans.name: Ekow

texts.en: Ekow, as he is popularly called by his numerous customers, is 41 year-old, local restaurant operator. He is married and blessed with 2 children. All his children are currently in school. In his restaurant, he prepares and sells rice dishes like jollof, waakye, fried rice, rice balls and "banku. Banku is prepared from milled maize grain and is taken with hot pepper or soup either in the morning, evening and afternoon. His food is very delicious and tasty and a lot of people buy from his stand. Ekow says that the prices of raw materials have gone up significantly and he needs the support of a loan to enable him meet his production expenditures. He wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials, like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood. Ekow belongs to a village bank called Believers of hope. He hopes to receive GH¢800 to make the business grow by restocking his inventory.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials, like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood.

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en: Millicent A. is 34 years old. She is married with one child. Millicent is into the sale of phone items like phone cards and credits cards. Millicent loves selling goods, the business through which she obtains daily source of livelihood. In Ghana we have communication networks like MTN, Tigo, Kasapa, Zain and Vodafone which was formally Ghana Telecom. She has been selling these cards for years to support her family. Mobile phone cards are purchase by many people due to the number of people who now have access to phones. She has attracted a lot of customers due to the friendly relations she keeps with them. She takes delivery of stock from wholesalers who provide her with a direct supply and retails these products to her customers. This enables her to avoid middlemen, who buy from the wholesalers and retail to her at higher prices. She belongs to a village bank called Yayra. She hopes to receive GH¢800 to make her business grow by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy phone items like phone cards and credits cards

loans.name: Maritza

texts.es:
La señora Maritza es socia del Banco Comunal “21 de Febrero”, distrito de Ilave, Provincia de El Collao, Departamento de Puno; tiene 25 años de edad, de estado civil casada, tiene 04 hijos y posee estudios de secundaría completa. 
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 04 años, se dedica al engorde de ganado menor (ovinos y porcinos); su primer préstamo fue de S/ 300.00 nuevos soles, con lo cual pudo adquirir ganado (ovinos) para venderlos como carne. 
Con este préstamo de S/ 600.00 nuevos soles, monto que se compromete a pagar en 03 cuotas mensuales; podrá adquirir mas ganado (ovejas cara negra) y engordarlos para venderlos en forma de carne en las ferias y mercados de Ilave, su anhelo es dedicarse también al engorde ganado mayor y ver profesionales a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Maritza is a member of the community bank 21 de Febrero, in Ilave district, Collao province, in the department of Puno. She is 25 years old, married, has four children, and has completed her high school education. Maritza has worked with the Manuela Ramos Movement for four years, and she’s in the business of raising small livestock (sheep and pigs). With her first loan of 300 soles, she was able to buy and raise more livestock (sheep) to sell for meat. With a new loan of 600 soles, which she plans to repay in three monthly installments, Maritza will be able to buy more blackface sheep to raise and sell for meat at the fairs and markets in Ilave. Maritza plans to become very skilled at raising livestock; she wants to set a professional example for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Corinne Gilroy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase and raise more livestock (blackface sheep), which can be sold for meat at fairs and markets in Ilave.

loans.name: Abiba

texts.en: Abiba I. is sixty five years old. She is a widow and has eight children. Due to financial constraints, after the death of her husband, all her children dropped out of school. Currently all of her children are learning trades. She is a food vendor and sells waakye and has been selling for the past thirty years to take care of her home. Waakye is cooked rice and beans enjoyed with stew, macaroni and fish. It is sold in the mornings as breakfast. It is very tasty and satisfying and almost all the tribes in Ghana enjoy waakye.  She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of rice, beans, fish etc. She belongs to a village bank called Fear Not. He hopes to receive GH¢800 to improve her business by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, beans and fish etc.

loans.name: Maria Cristina

texts.es:
Maria Cristina inició el negocio  por la necesidad de tener un ingreso que le permitiera salir adelante y de ser una mujer independiente, sin miedo a los retos y trascender como persona y como madre, realizando lo que le gusta que son las ventas y obteniendo un ingreso para sostener a sus hijas ya que quedo viuda. Comenzó el negocio en Abril de 1996 vendiendo un poco de todo, primeramente ropa, luego tuvo una tiendita, luego vendió también joyería de oro y cerámica y después abrió una papelería y hace cuatro años fue que comenzó a vender adornos rústicos, que es la única actividad que desempeña al día de hoy y en la cual le ha ido muy bien, ya que cada vez tengo mas clientes que compran sus productos y por lo mismo ha logrado incrementar sus ganancias.

Ella necesita un préstamo por MXN $4,000 que pagara en 8 catorcenas, con este dinero va a comprar más mercancía que le permita tener una mayor variedad de productos para sus clientes.
texts.en:
Maria Cristina started her business out of the necessity to have an income that lets her move ahead, be an independent woman, not be afraid of challenges and improve as a person. As a mother, she likes to sell goods and obtain an income to support her daughters, now that she is a widow. She started her business in April of 1996, selling a little of everything. At first she sold clothes, then she had a small general store, then she also sold gold jewelry and ceramics. Then she opened a stationary shop and for 4 years ago she began selling country decorations, which is all she does now. This has been doing very well, and she is always getting new customers to buy her products. Her earnings have increased because of this.

She needs a loan of 4,000 Mexican pesos, and she will pay it in 8 2-week periods. With this money she is going to buy more merchandise that will let her have a larger variety of products for her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Caitlin Brooks, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort B. is 45 years old. She is a widow and a mother of five kids. She lives in the greater Accra region of Ghana. Her husband died after a prolong sickness. Comfort, a single parent, is very resourceful to her family in providing food and paying of bills. She lives at the capital city of Ghana. Comfort is a food vendor and sells kenkey. Kenkey is prepared from milled maize grain, cooked and eaten with hot pepper and fried fish. She has many customers as many Ghanaians enjoy kenkey for breakfast, lunch or supper. 

Comfort wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables, firewood etc. She hopes to increase her savings to support her children's education. She belongs to village bank called “Fear Not”. She hopes to receive GH¢600 to make her business grow by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables, firewood etc.

loans.name: Socorro Guadalupe

texts.es:
Socorro inició el negocio por la necesidad tener una entrada extra de dinero, ya que aunque es empleada de ventas en una empresa que se dedica a la fabricación de tintas plásticas, el sueldo que percibo no  es suficiente por lo que decidió comenzar su negocio  en Julio de 1998 en un cumpleaños de una de sus hijas elaboro algunos arreglos infantiles y le gustaron mucho a sus amigas, fue entonces que decidió arriesgarse a elaborarlos para su venta y a la gente le ha gustado mucho su trabajo lo cual ha hecho que cada día tenga mas clientes.
Gracias  a su esfuerzo su negocio ha ido progresando considerablemente ya que inicio  haciendo pocos arreglos pero en la actualidad la gente ya conoce su trabajo y además de hacer sus arreglos, desde hace seis meses ya también se dedica a la impresión de invitaciones, vasos, servilletas, etc

Ella necesita un préstamo por MXN $4000 que pagara en 8 catorcenas lo que le permitirá contar con suficiente materia prima para poder elaborar arreglos ahora que se acerca el 14 de febrero, día de san Valentín en donde la gente organiza fiestas y hace regalos.
texts.en:
Socorro started her business out of the necessity to have extra income, although she is employed in the sales of a company that makes dyed plastics, the income of which is not enough to be dedicated to starting a business. In July of 1998, on the birthday of one of her daughters, she made some arrangements for children (with toys, candy and decorations), and her friends liked them a lot. She then decided to make them to sell, and everyone has liked her work a lot. She makes them every day for her customers.

Thank you for your support of her business. The business has progressed considerably since it she started making the arrangements. Everyone now knows her work. and for 5 months she has been making invitation cards, glasses, napkins, etc.

She needs a loan of 4,000 Mexican pesos that she will pay in 8 2-week periods. This will let her have enough primary materials to elaborate her products, now that it is around February 14th, Saint Valentine's Day, when everyone has parties and gives gifts.

Translated from Spanish by Caitlin Brooks, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy material for her work

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy N. is 26 years old, single and independent. She has been sewing for five years and is a specialist in fladies wears. Her skills and designs are classy. She has operated a seamstress shop for the past four years. She is training one young lady in sewing and will equip her with skills and experience for her future career. She sews all forms ladies wear in various kinds of styles like kaba and slit, wedding dresses, funeral clothes, etc.

Mercy wants to use the loan to buy more sewing materials like linen, threads, thimbles, etc. to increase her output and efficiency. She hopes to increase her savings to support her kids in school. With the loan she believes her dream would be fulfilled by taking care of her family. Mercy belongs to the village bank called “Fear Not”. She hopes to receive GH¢1000 to improve her business by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more sewing materials like linen, threads, thimbles, etc.

loans.name: Maria Olga

texts.es:
Olga inició el negocio por que años anteriores también manejo el negocio de venta de ropa por un periodo de 3 años, lo dejo  pero después quiso volver con la ventas ya se había acostumbrado a tener un  ingreso adicional además que conoce mucha gente pero  se decidió por la venta de cosméticos y le agrado mas este negocio y siente que además que lo maneja mucho mejor  le va muy bien y tiene mucha facilidad para vender. 
Comenzó el negocio hace 5 años primero quería surtir algunos perfumes y cremas solamente ayudándole a una persona para así ver ella  como se sentía siguió metiendo pedidos pero ya por su cuenta viendo que la gente respondía y pasaron alrededor de 8 meses y de repente vio que tenia muchísima clientela  y le pedían de todo cremas cosméticos perfumes tratamientos  para darse abasto pidió el crédito para tener existencia de mercancía antes tenia que ofrecer a diario por las casas de la gente que conocía pero ahora en la actualidad los mismos clientes llegan solos.
El negocio de la Sra. Olga ha crecido gracias a  sus familiares y vecinos que la Han ido recomendando.

Ella necesita un préstamo por MXN $10,000 que pagara en 12 catorcenas para comprar mercancía y  tener  perfumes ya que por la temporada la línea para la que vende ofrece paquetes a precios accesibles y así ella ya los tiene en existencia.
texts.en:
Olga started business because before she had been operating a business selling clothes for 3 years, and when that ended she wanted to return to retail. She had been used to additional income and she started selling cosmetics. She liked this business a lot and she felt like she could do it much better. She very happy to be in retail.

She started business 5 years ago to sell some perfumes and creams, just as an assistant to a person and she could see how to do the work. She felt like following orders and about 8 months passed. She saw that she was suddenly getting a lot of customers and they were asking for a lot of cosmetic creams, treatments and perfumes. She sells to her friends who now come to her on their own. Olga's business has been beneficial for her friends and neighbors, and she is often recommended.

She needs a loan of 10000 Mexican pesos that she will pay in 12 2-week periods. It will be used to buy merchandise. She will have perfumes of limited lines to offer in packets at accessible prices and this way she will stay in business.

Translated from Spanish by Caitlin Brooks, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Alima

texts.en:
Alima A. started her local restaurant ten years ago in Bawaleshie, a suburb of Accra, where she lives. Since then, she has become one of the most popular food vendors in her neighborhood. She is now 42 years old, married and mother with six children. She serves many kinds of local dishes, like fufu, rice balls, and banku, among others. Fufu is prepared from pounded cassava and plantain and taken with soup. Banku is prepared from milled maize grain and taken with hot pepper or soup.

Alima wants to use this loan to buy more supplies, like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, and firewood. She also hopes to use part of the proceeds to finance her children who are in school. She belongs to a group called Fear Not. She hopes to receive GH¢1000 to make her business grow by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more supplies like, bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, and firewood.

loans.name: Martín Alejandro

texts.es:
El señor Martín Alejandro J. vive en una casa prestada junto con su esposa y su hijo. 
Como desea tener su propia vivienda es por eso que está tramitando una casa por medio de Infonavit (Crédito Gubernamental), pero el valor de la vivienda es superior al crédito que el puede recibir ya que su sueldo es bajo. 
  El trabaja como mecánico automotriz en una compañía y en horario adicional a su trabajo también realiza otros trabajos de mecánica a particulares. Por tal motivo está solicitando un préstamo para completar el crédito Gubernamental y así adquirir su casa. 
Ya que desea tener un patrimonio y al seguro para su familia.
texts.en:
Martin Alejandro Jimenez lives in a borrowed home with his wife and his child. He wants to have his own home which is why he is negotiating the purchase of a house through Infonavit (a government loan). However, the cost of the home is higher than the loan he can receive because his salary is low. Martin works as a car mechanic at a company and he also does additional mechanic jobs on the side. He is requesting a loan so that he can complete the government loan to purchase his home as he wants to have an asset and be able to provide security for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Down payment to acquire his home through Infonavit (government loan)

loans.name: Juan

texts.es:
Juan inició el negocio porque siempre le han gustado las ventas ya que trabajo 13 años en una mueblería de la localidad adquirió experiencia en lo que es el manejo de la cartera, las ventas y la cobranza, cuando su  familia empezó a crecer e incrementarse los gastos y al ver que no  completaba con los gastos, fue que  surgió  la necesidad de tener su propio negocio para darles una mejor calidad de vida. Comenzó en octubre del 2001, y su negocio ha progresado mucho ya que hoy en día cuenta con una buena cartera de clientes, buen inventario, varios muebles y dos casas.

El necesita un préstamo por MXN $10,000 que pagara en 12 catorcenas para comprar mercancía y continuar con su negocio.
texts.en:
Juan started his company because he has always like working in sales. He worked for 13 years in a local furniture store where he gained experience in managing money, selling and charging customers. His family and expenses began growing and his salary no longer covered household expenses, so it became necessary for him to open his own business in order to improve their quality of life. He opened in October of 2001 and his business has grown a lot. Today he enjoys a good clientele, good inventory, various pieces of furniture and two houses. He needs this loan for 10,000 pesos, which he will repay in 12 bi-monthly payments, to buy more merchandise to continue his business.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: expand merchandise

loans.name: Francisco Javier

texts.es:
Francisco inició el negocio por que fue una de las actividades que aprendió cuando trabajo fuera de la ciudad, y con lo que le pagaban iba guardando una parte para comprar maquinaria y equipo a buen precio eso con la idea de en un futuro poner su propio negocio e independizarse y así no dejar la familia sola teniendo que salir a trabajar fuera.

Comenzó su negocio de elaboracion de puertas y ventanas de aluminio a finales del 2005 primero haciendo trabajos a los familiares dándose a conocer con ellos  y con las amistades los cuales a la vez le fueron recomendando y así ha logrado tener una buena cantidad de clientes

Su negocio ha ido progresando ya que ha aumentando el equipo para  realizar trabajos mas sofisticados y también eso le permite que cuando tiene muchos pedidos puede emplear a trabajadores para sacar mas rápido los encargos que le hacen los clientes.

El necesita un préstamo por MXN $6,000 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar material de trabajo para continuar con su negocio.
texts.en:
Francisco started his business after he learned his trade when he left the city for work. He saved part of each of his paychecks to buy tools and equipment at a low price, with the idea of opening his own business someday. This way he could be independent and not have to leave his family behind to find work. At the end of 2005 he opened his business making doors and aluminum windows. He started by doing projects for his relatives and friends, who in turn recommended his work to other friends, and that’s how he now has a good number of clients. His business has been growing and he has purchased more equipment in order to complete more sophisticated projects. Also, when he has a lot of orders, he is able to hire other people to help him complete the projects more quickly for his customers. He is asking for 6,000 pesos which he will pay in 6 months in order to buy materials and continue his business.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: work materials

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa M. is thirty eight years old and married with two children. All of her children are still in the school. Hawa lives with her family at Bawalashie a suburb of Accra in Ghana. She loves fashion very much and as a result, trades in jewels like ear rings, necklaces, etc. She has been selling jewelry for the last ten years. Hawa buys her goods from Agbobloshie market which is also a suburb of Accra. She hawks with her goods from house to house and also treks to nearby markets to sell. However, she is constrained with funds to make her business grow in order to meet her family's needs. 

Hawa wants to use the loan to buy jewelry in bulk so she can sell at more markets. Hawa is in a village bank called ‘Fear Not’. She hopes to receive GH¢800 to improve her business by restocking her inventory. It has been her dream that her children acquire a quality education.

loans.use: To buy jewelry in bulk for resale

loans.name: Reyna  Graciela

texts.es:
Reyna es casada y tiene 7 hijos, inició el negocio  porque necesitaba una entrada de dinero para sostener a sus hijos, porque  tiene que sacar adelante a sus hijos ya que todos estudian y quiere darles lo mejor. Comenzó el negocio en Octubre de 1998, por invitación de una de sus primas que la llevó a una demostración de cosméticos y así se inicio vendiendo entre sus vecinas y amistades, ya que además trabaja como empleada doméstica y los fines de semana vende comida y novedades y regalos en los mercados rodantes.  Además sus hijos le ayudan en las labores de cobranza y entrega de mercancía.
le ha ido muy bien, ya que con los cosméticos cada vez tiene mas clientas y así mejores ganancias que puede invertir en otros productos que vende como son novedades y regalos y así es como ha ido creciendo.

Ella necesita un préstamo por MXN $3000 que pagara en 6 catorcrenas para invertir en cosméticos, regalos y novedades y así tener una mejor variedad de productos que pueda ofrecer a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Reyna is married and has 7 children. She started her business because she needed a source of income to support her children, wanting to send them all to school and give them all the best there is. She started out in October 1998 through an invitation from a cousin who brought her a cosmetics demonstration and that's how she started selling to her neighbours and friends. She also works cleaning homes on the weekends and selling foods, souvenirs and gifts in the area markets. She also has her children helping her by collecting payments and delivering merchandise.

It has gone very well for her with the cosmetics because each time she has more clients and better earnings that she can invest in other products for sale, such as souvenirs and gift items, which is how she has been expaning the business.

She requires a loan of $3000 MXN that will be repaid in 6 biweekly terms to invest in her cosmetics, gift items and souvenirs. She will have a better variety of products to offer her clients.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in merchandise.

loans.name: Adriana Marcela

texts.es:
Adriana inició el negocio para sentirse útil, ya que después de que se caso y dejo de trabajar necesitaba realizar alguna actividad y empezó a invertir el dinero que ahorraba en el negocio que tenía de taxis para invertir en la joyería y no tener que depender completamente de su esposo. Comenzó el negocio en Abril de 2006 por invitación de una de sus amigas a la cual también habían invitado a vender joyería de plata por lo que decido invertir sus ahorros y fue como empezó a vender entres sus amistades, vecinos y familiares, desde que empezó le ha ido muy bien y en la actualidad ya tiene un buen número de clientes y  ha ganado premios por seruna de las vendedoras “estrella” en su grupo de trabajo.

Ella necesita un préstamo por MXN $3,000 que pagara en 6 catorcenas para comprar más artículos de joyería de plata para tener un mejor surtido que ofrecer a sus clientes aprovechando que se acerca el 14 de Febrero ya que en esa fecha a la gente le gusta regalar cosas
texts.en:
Adriana started her business to feel purposeful. After she married and stopped working she needed to start some kind of work and so she invested money that she saved from the taxi business she once had to invest in a jewlery store and not have to depend completely on her husband. She started out in April 2006 through an invitation from a friend who had also been invited to sell silver jewlery. She decided to invest her savings and started selling to her friends, neighbours and family, and since she started it has gone very well for her. Currentlly she has a good number of clients and she has won recognition as being one fo the "star" salespeople in her work group.

She requires a loan of $3000 MXN, which will be repaid in 6 biweeklly payments, to purchase more silver jewlery items, to have better selection to offer her clients, taking into account that February 14 is fast approaching. In this season people enjoy giving gifts.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys A. is forty years old married woman with two children who are in the high school. Gladys lives with her family in Shiashie in Ghana. She runs a small provisions kiosk in her neighborhood. She also sells second hand clothes. She has been in business for five years. Gladys buys her goods from wholesalers in the city of Accra and treks to markets in nearby towns. Gladys wants a larger working capital. She would like to buy her goods in bulk whenever she travels to the city in order to reduce the problem of frequent treks. 

Gladys' village bank is called “fear not”. She hopes to receive GH¢500 to improve her business by restocking her inventory. It has been her dream to equip her children with a quality education. With the loan she believes it would enable her to expand her kiosk in the market center.

loans.use: To buy bulk supplies of used cloths

loans.name: Irma

texts.es:
Irma Gómez inició el negocio porque necesitaba un ingreso extra que le permitiera ayudar a su esposo con los gastos de la casa y los estudios de sus hijos, sobre todo después que se pensionó su esposo el dinero les alcanzaba menos. Comenzó su negocio en enero de 2007 por iniciativa propia, ya que tenía ahorrado algún dinero y decidió invertir en una tienda pequeña, la cual puso en la parte de enfrente de su casa, aprovechando que vivo en una esquina y que no había ninguna otra tienda cercana. Desde que empezó ha ido creciendo poco a poco y ya los vecinos de la zona la conocen y por lo mismo cuenta con un buen número de clientes por lo esta pensando también en vender frutas y verduras.

Ella necesita un préstamo pro MXN $3,000 que pagara en 6 catorcenas que le  permitirá comprar más abarrotes para tener mejor surtida su tienda y dar un mejor servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Irma G. started her business because she needed an extra income to help out her husband with the household expenses and with their childrens' schooling, especially because her husband retired and their income was less.
