Her product selection consists of national women’s dresses, robes and trousers with different hand embroidery and braiding, which she sews herself at home. She also sells fabric with designs, for national dresses and trousers. With Kiva’s help, Dilbar would like to take out a loan for $825 (3000 somoni) in order to increase her product selection.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials and accessories

loans.name: Idibek

texts.ru:
Молодой предприниматель 4 года занимается торговлей.  Меликов Идибек родился 1984 года, женат и имеет 1 ребенка. Он в оптовом рынке «Корвон» города Душанбе торгует женскими одеждами. В его ассортименте разнообразные национальные платья, штаны, халаты. Закупает он товар у лиц, которые дома шьют. Местом его деятельности является рынок "Корвон" города Душанбе.
Идибек хочет получить займ 1500 сомони для увеличения ассортимента и тем самым увеличить свой товарооборот.
texts.en:
The young entrepreneur has been working in sales for 4 years. Idibek M. was born in 1984. He is married and has one child. He sells women’s clothing at the “Korvon” wholesale market in Dushanbe. His product assortment includes a variety of traditional dresses, trousers and robes. He purchases his products from individuals who sew them at home. His place of business is the “Korvon” market in Dushaben. Idibek would like to take out a $425 (1500 somoni) loan in order to increase his product assortment and increase his inventory. .

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase traditional women's clothing for sale

loans.name: Shaja Mohammad Group

texts.en:
Shaja M. is the group leader of the Shaja M. group. There are four members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for their businesses.

Arafa and Hamyra want to receive a loan for their tailoring business. They want to buy two new machines for their business.  Makhtar Ahmad  wants to receive a loan for his general store. He wants to buy necessary material for his business and complete his stock. Shaja M. wants to receive a loan for his fruit cart business. 

They want to say that these loans will be used in full for growing their businesses. They all want to thank Kiva for its efforts in Afghanistan to support poor people.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.ru:
Шоева Махбуба 1988 года рождения. Она живет с родителями в районе Рудаки. Благодаря тёте, которая научила ее шить и вышивать, Махбубу уже хорошо знают в своем районе. Она занимается шитьем национальных платьев, а также вышивкой.  Ее девиз «Клиент – всегда прав»! Учитываю этот девиз, она старается  угождать своим клиентом разновидностью фасонов и орнаментами, которые сама вышивает. Махбуба вышивает необычные узоры. 
Махбуба также закупает материал и шьет халаты, которых закупают продавцы с рынка «Корвон» и сейчас она хочет получить займ 1500 сомони сроком 6 месяцев, чтобы купить материал и нитки.
texts.en:
Mahbuba S. was born in 1988. She lives with her parents in the Rudaki area. Thanks to her aunt who taught her to sew and embroider, Mahbuba is already well known in her neighborhood. She sews traditional dresses and also embroiders. Her motto is “The client - is always right!” Given her motto, she tries to serve her clients by providing a variety of styles and decorations, which she embroiders herself. Mahbuba embroiders unusual patterns. Mahbuba also purchases fabric and sews housecoats, which are purchased by the sellers at the “Korvon” market and she would like to take out a 6 month loan for $425 (150 somoni) in order to purchase fabric and thread. .

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fabric and thread

loans.name: Quang Thi's Group

texts.vi:
Nguyễn Thị Quang sinh năm 1968,( mã số: 010117090063 ). Vợ chồng chị làm nghề mổ lợn đem bán ở chợ. Gia đình vẫn làm nông nghiệp. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình khoảng 300.000 đến 350.000 vnđ. Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ đề mua hàng. Chị là nhóm trưởng nhóm vay vốn gồm có:
 Lê Thị Thuỷ sinh năm 1963, ,( mã số: 010117090064 ) chị làm ruộng, chồng sửa chữa xe đạp, xe máy, hai con đang đi học. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình khoảng 300.000 vnđ/tuần. Chị vay mức: 4.142.000 vnđ để mua hàng.
 Nguyễn Thị M. sinh năm 1975, ,( mã số: 010117090065 ) chị làm thợ may và bán áo vải. chồng chị đi xuất khẩu lao động, hai con đi học. Chị vay mức vốn vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để lấy hàng.
 Trần Thị Dương sinh năm 1972, ,( mã số: 010117090066 ) chị làm nghề bán hang giải khát. Chị phải một nách nuôi hai đứa con. Chị vay mức vốn vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư hàng giải khát.
 Nguyễn Thị Huyền sinh năm 1977, ( mã số: 010117090067 ) chị cũng bán hang giải khát, chồng chị làm bảo vệ trông x echo bệnh viện. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình khoảng 300.000 vnđ/tuần. Chị vay mức vốn: 4.142.000 vnđ để lấy thêm hàng.
texts.en:
Mrs. Quang T. N. was born in 1968. She and her husband work as pig butchers, and they sell the meat at the market. The family also raises livestock. Their average income is about 300,000 VND to 350,000 VND. She joined the Fund with a loan of 4,142,000 VND to buy stock. She is the group leader in this group loan, which includes: -Mrs. T. T. Le, born 1963. She works the fields, while her husband fixes bicycles and scooters. Their two children are attending school. The family's average income is about 300 VND per week. She is borrowing 4,142,000 VND to buy stock. -Mrs. M. T. N. was born in 1975. She is a tailor and also sells fabric shirts. Her husband is a migrant worker working overseas. Their two children are going to school. She is borrowing 4,142,000 VND to buy stock. -Mrs. D. T. Tran was born in 1972. She sells beverages. She raises her two children as a single mother. She is borrowing 4,142,000 VND to invest in buying beverages to sell. -Mrs. H. T. N. was born in 1977. She also sells beverages while her husband works as a security guard guarding cars for hospitals. Their average income is about 300,000 VND per week. She is borrowing 4,142,000 VND to buy more stock.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi N., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in their small businesses, buying more stock goods

loans.name: Sum

texts.en: Sum C. is 34 years old and lives with her husband in the Bati district of Takeo province. She is a farmer who grows and sells rice to earn a living. She makes around $1 a day. Her husband earns about $5 a day driving a motor-taxi. She and her husband have five children. Mrs. Sum would like to take out a loan to raise pigs and to make rice wine.

loans.use: To raise pigs and make rice wine

loans.name: Ven

texts.en: Ven T. is 40 years old and lives with her husband in the Bati district, Takeo province. To earn a living, she grows rice and sells noodles from her home. On average, she makes about $1 of profit per day. Her husband, shown in the photo, fixes TVs and radios. He makes about $6 a day. This couple has six children, four of whom are in school and two of whom are too young to attend school. Mrs. Ven T. is asking for a loan to purchase tools for her husband's work.

loans.use: To purchase tools

loans.name: Ven

texts.en: Ven T. is 31 years old and works as a driver. He purchases local fruits and transports them to sell at the provincial market to earn a living. He makes $9 a day. His wife grows rice and vegetables, earning less than one dollar a day. This couple has three school-aged children. Mr. Ven is asking for a loan to purchase fruits in bulk to sell at the provincial market.

loans.use: To buy fruit in bulk for resale

loans.name: Or

texts.en: Or V., 21, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province, Cambodia. She works with her husband making incense from their home, to earn a living. They are able to make about $5 of profit per day. She would like to use this loan to purchase a motorbike and increase the number of incense sticks that they sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en: Soeun C., 43, is married and lives with her husband in Battambang province, Cambodia. She sells fish at the market to earn a living. On average she makes $7 every day, while her husband earns $5 working as a construction worker. This couple has six children, two are construction workers and four are in school. Mrs. Soeun C. is asking for a loan to purchase a motorbike to transport the fish that she sells at the market. Every morning, she goes to buy fish at a lake that is not far from the market, but must take public transportation to get to the market. This costs her significantly, and is the reason why she decided to take out a loan to purchase her own bike.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to transport fish to the market

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.en:
Vicenta N. sells clothes. She uses her profit to pay all her family's daily expenses including tuition fees of her four children and their other needs. She is 44 years old and lives in Maribojoc, Bohol, a town of 18,113 people. Her husband, Wilfredo N., is very supportive of her in her business. They work together to uplift their lives. She previously worked as a daycare teacher. She was not happy about her job and decided to venture into selling clothes in the flea market.

Vicenta is asking for a loan of 9,000 pesos. She will use the loan to buy additional stocks of clothes to sell. She believes that her loan will bring her more profits. This would definitely help her family address their needs.

CEVI is giving all its clients the credit assistance they need in their businesses. CEVI also provides trainings and insurance coverage to all its clients to help them increase their sales. In this way, CEVI can create a lasting impact on so many lives.

loans.use: To buy additional stocks of clothes to sell.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan K. of Battambang province is 25 years old and has a business as a tailor. She is also a wedding planner. She is a widow who lives with her young child. On average, she makes around $6 a day. She would like to take out a loan to purchase cosmetic products and clothes for her tailoring business.

loans.use: clothes and cosmetics

loans.name: Maleyka

texts.en: Maleyka J. is a 61 year old woman who sells various kinds of home products from her store. She started her business in 1993 as the salary she earned wasn't enough to cover the basic family needs. Maleyka also works as nurse in the local hospital. Maleyka`s main source of income is her store. She is not alone with the store as her husband helps her in this business. Now Maleyka would like to expand her business along with her income. For this reason she has applied for a 1200 USD loan with a term of 15 month to purchase more inventory for her store. Lets help this hardworking woman.

loans.use: Purshase food products

loans.name: Noy

texts.en: Noy B., 57, is married and lives with her husband (pictured here) and her child in the Battambang province. She and her husband raise chickens and grow rice to earn a living, and are able to make a combined $4 every day. This couple hopes to use this loan to build a cage and expand their livestock by adding more chickens and purchasing more feed.

loans.use: Buy livestock and feed

loans.name: Inocenta

texts.en: Mrs. Inocenta A., 64 years old, is married and lives at Butuay, Jimenez, Mis. Occidental. She has 2 children. Her husband is a village electrician and a farmer. In order to help her husband, she decided to raise pigs for additional income. Mrs. A. heard of Paglaum MPC and joined the cooperative because of the benefits given to members aside from loans. She already availed herself of loans several times, being a Member in Good Standing. Now, she applies for PHP 14,900 to buy sacks of feed for daily consumption by her pigs. Someday she wants to raise more pigs for sale and to own a piggery. She plans also to renovate her house.

loans.use: To buy sacks of animal feeds

loans.name: Inn

texts.en: Inn L., 33, lives with her husband in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 2003, she has been raising pigs and selling them to the market to earn approximately $4 a day. Her husband stays at home and helps her raise the pigs. This couple has five children, three of whom are in school and two who are at home. Mrs. Inn L. is asking for a loan to breed more pigs and purchase feed.

loans.use: Buy pigs and feed

loans.name: Kaundime

texts.en:
Kaundime has been a coconut, cassava and clothes seller in the Mwera neighborhood of Zanzibar for 3 years. She belongs to Nia Moja loan group. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $40. Every day she works at her business. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more coconuts, cassava and clothes for her business. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Kaundime is 28 years old, married, and has two children, ages 5 and 2.

loans.use: To buy more coconuts, cassava and clothes for her business.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
"A responsible woman" best describes Mrs Merly M., 35 years old, married and living at Mohon, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She was blessed with 4 children. Her husband is a carpenter. They also have a small piece of land, inherited from their parents, for farming and coconut growing to generate quarterly income. After the farm harvest, they had the idea of raising ducks in order to utilize the land as well as earn additional income through selling the eggs, which are boiled in water and sold as a popular delicacy known as “Balut”.

In order to finance & acquire capital for their land cultivation & duck raising, they decided to join Paglaum MP Cooperative. Mrs. Merly M., being the member, had already availed herself of several loans. Now, she is applying for PHP 14,900 to buy feed for ducks and fertilizers for her farm. Someday, she will be fulfilled seeing her children finish their studies.

loans.use: To buy feed for duck raising

loans.name: Mtumwa

texts.en:
Mtumwa has had a small shop and has been a cassava seller in the Mwera neighborhood of Zanzibar for 2 years. She belongs to the Penyeriziki loan group. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $80. Every day she works at her business from 8 a.m. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more shop items and cassava for her business. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Mtumwa is 39 years old, married, and has four children, ages 15, 9, 7, and 3.

loans.use: To buy more cassava and shop items for her business

loans.name: Eak

texts.en: Eak S., 31, is married and lives with her husband in the Bati district, Takeo province. Currently, she is pregnant and works at a grocery store, earning around US$2 of profit every day. Her husband stays at home and helps her sell grocery products. Mrs. Eak S. is asking for a loan to expand her grocery store by adding more stuff to meet her clients' demand.

loans.use: To purchase grocery products.

loans.name: Chang

texts.en: Chang T. is married and lives with her husband and three children in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband work selling rice in the community. On average, they make a combined $7 per day. This couple hopes to use this loan to purchase more rice stock.

loans.use: rice stock

loans.name: Bakir

texts.en:
Bakir M. is a 42-year-old cattle breeder who raises livestock in the small village of Imishli. He has been engaged in this business from a young age because his father and grandfather were farmers. He got experience in looking after cattle and does not have any higher education.

Bakir is married and has two children, who are studying at school. Bakir would like to expand his business and purchase two more calves and fodder.

loans.use: Purchase two more calves

loans.name: Chel

texts.en: Chel S., 30, is married and lives with her two young children in Takeo province. She grows rice and also works as tailor, earning around US$1 each day, while her husband works as a moto-taxi driver making US$2 each day. Mrs. Chel S. would like to take out a loan of $500 to purchase a cow to plow her farmland and buy more cloth for her tailoring business.

loans.use: To purchase cow and cloth.

loans.name: Mwantum

texts.en:
Mwantum has been a clothes seller in the Mwera neighborhood of Zanzibar for 2 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $155. Every day she works at her business for 8 hours. She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes for her business. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business 

Mwantum is 32 years old, widowed, and has two children: ages 12 and 5.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Mang

texts.en: Mang T. is 26 years old and lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She stays at home looking her after children and raising pigs to make a living, and is able to earn about $8 in revenue every day. Her husband makes $10 a day working as a taxi driver. This couple has three children and one of them is in school. Mang T. is asking for a loan to purchase rice to resell when the price is high.

loans.use: rice to resell

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Fatma has owned a small general store in the Mwera neighborhood of Zanzibar for 2 years. She belongs to the Nia njema loan group (Group code 2007). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $25. Every day she works at her business. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items (meat and soap) for her business. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business 

Fatma is 22 years old, married, and has one child.

loans.use: To buy meat, soap and other items for her busness.

loans.name: Thai

texts.en: Thai O., 48, is married and lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She purchases rubber and sells it wholesale to the market, earning approximately $1.30 per day. Her husband makes around $3.50 a day  working as a taxi driver. This couple has four children, two of who are employed as construction workers and two are in school. Mrs. Thai is asking for a loan to purchase a new motorbike for her husband as the old one often breaks down and uses a lot of gas.

loans.use: Purchase new motorcycle

loans.name: Eang

texts.en: Eang S. is 47 years old (pictured here with her husband) and is a fish seller in a busy market. She has been operating this business since 2000 and is able to make $7 of profit every day. Her husband digs wells and makes $8 a day. Currently, she and her husband live with their two employed children. Eang S. is asking for a loan to create a new business selling spare parts. This will provide the family with additional income to raise their standard of living.

loans.use: setting up new business

loans.name: Aumbe

texts.en:
Aumbe has been selling shoes in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 10 years. She belongs to the Farajika loan group. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $90. She works at her business every day. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more shoes for her business. She is hopping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to expand her business. 

Aumbe is 35 years old and is married with five children aged 13, 12, 10, and 8 years and a 9-month old baby.

loans.use: To buy more shoes for her business.

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en:
Soeun R. is 32 years old and lives with his wife in Kandal province. He catches fish and sells his catch in the market, where he earns approximately $6 USD every day. His wife grows vegetables on her farm and makes about $5 USD each day. This couple has three childR., all of whom are in school. 

To catch fish to sell, fishermen need to pay the fishery officer a fee to rent the area in which catch fish. Mr. Soeun R. would like a loan to rent the fishing area to catch fish. 

Mr. Soeun R. is pictured on his wife’s farm.

loans.use: To rent a fishing area.

loans.name: Mrs. Yin Prak Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fourteen people living in Saeprambei village in Kampong Cham province comprise this village bank loan group. They will use the loan for various purposes. 

Mrs. Yin P., the 36-year-old village bank president, is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she grows rice. She can earn a little income on her farm to support her household. Thus, has she decided to request a loan, which she will use with her savings to buy a piece of land to grow vegetables and earn more income. Her husband, Mr. Yoem Yin, is a laborer. Mrs. Yin P. has four children, two of whom are laborers. The others attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy a piece of land to grow vegetables

loans.name: Muazzam

texts.ru: Муаззам удачно закончила очередной займ и хочет ещё получить кредит.С каждым месяцем у неё оборот меняет ассортимент, т.е увеличивается и становится разнообразным.Муаззам женщина которая зря время не теряет, а старается улучшить положение семьи и увеличить свой оборотный капитал.
texts.en:
Muazzam successfully repaid her last loan and would like to receive another. Every month her inventory changes with turnover; that is, it expands and diversifies. Muazaam is a woman who does not waste time. Instead she constantly strives to improve her family's position and increase her working capital.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Shoes

loans.name: Thorn

texts.en: Thorn P. is 25 years old and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She is a true entrepreneur who has a business selling clothes at the market. On average, she makes $15 in revenue every day. Her husband is a policeman and earns $4 a day. She and her husband have one little child. She would like to request a loan to add more clothes to her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros M. is a woman from Mag-aba, Pandan, and Antique who runs a variety store. Even though she is 70 years old, she has no trouble running her business. She was married to Mr. Balvino M. who, fortunately, was very supportive and served as the storekeeper while she managed her business.

She received a P5,000.00 loan ($125 USD) and used it to purchase items such as beer, sardines, sugar and rice. She established her variety store with a little capital from her sister. Most of her customers were her neighbors.This loan helped her to buy additional products to satisfy her customers.

Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. was a great help, not only on the financial side, but also in personality development. Now, she always has a positive outlook on life because of the support of the ASHI staff.

loans.use: Variety Store

loans.name: Zulfiyya

texts.en:
Zulfiyya A. is 40-year-old woman who runs her own small business raising sheep and cattle for meat production. She sells fattened and raised animals to the local livestock bazaar or to the restaurants. She has been in this business since she got married. Because she was unemployed, her husband offered her an opportunity to begin raising cattle. Soon, this business start bringing stable income to her family, which consists of three children. 

Zulfiyya would like to expand her sheep herd and purchase one more calf. For this purpose, she has applied for a loan of $1200 USD to purchase five sheep, one calf and fodder. Zulfiyya and her family count on you for your help.

loans.use: To purchase five sheep, one calf, and fodder.

loans.name: Ramona

texts.en:
Through her initiative, Mrs. Ramona N. established a variety store. She has received a loan to purchase groceries and additional products to increase her inventory. Ramona  was born in Pandan and was blessed with four (4) children. She is widowed, and rearing her children and sending them to school was a challenge.
	She received her P5, 000.00 loan on January 22, 2009 and purchased supplies of groceries for her variety store. This new inventory will add to the convenience of her customers. Her customers are her neighbors and the people who visit at the local Barangay hall. At the moment her variety store stand is her sister's property and it is very useful to her business.
	Ramona plans to expand her business to add new products for fishing and construction materials. She dreams that she will be able to send her grandchild to school and to build a house where she can live permanently.

loans.use: Variety Store

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Ftama has been selling snacks in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for the past 6 months. She belongs to the H'Tamaa loan group (Group code 2035).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $25. She works at her business 10 hours a day. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more snacks for her business. She hopes that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business. 

Fatma is 22 years old and single.

loans.use: To buy more snacks for resale and expand her business

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mao D., 31, is married and sells charcoal in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She has been in this business for about six years. She makes US$3 every day. Her husband, pictured here, is a recycler and earns $1.5 a day. She and her husband have five children. Three are students and two are too young to attend school. Mrs. Mao would like to take out a loan to purchase a motorbike to transport charcoal.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Mr. Chhorn Prum Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank, which consists of fourteen members, is located in Saeprambei village in Kampong Cham province and they plan to use the loan which they obtained for different purposes. Mr. Chhorn P. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. He is a laborer in the local village. His wife, Mrs. Mouk Sameith, is a housewife. Although they try to work hard, they still live in poor conditions. In order to provide a better life for their family, Mr. Chhorn P. wants to start a business purchasing general goods to re-sell to earn more income. Mr. Chhorn P. is 60 years old and the father of a child who is a laborer.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy general goods to re-sell.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mao D., 46, is married and lives with her husband and four of her children in the Kampong Chhnang province.  Since 2006, she has been selling food and rice in the market to earn a living, and is able to make around US$4 every day. Her husband earns about US$5 working as a journalist. Two of their children are students and two are employed as workers in a Hotel in Siem Reap province. As rice selling is making less profit, Mrs. Mao D. is asking for a loan to create a new business selling children shoes. She expects the switch will increase her profits to support her family.

loans.use: To invest in a new  business - selling children's shoes

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
Khadija has been a juice and ice cream seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 2 years. She belongs to the V'Imara loan group (Group code 2038).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $80. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business. 

Khadija is 42 years old, married, and has seven children: ages 24, 21, 18, 16, 12, 9 and 4

loans.use: To expand her business by buying more items for resale.

loans.name: Choun

texts.en: Choun S., 36, lives with her husband and daughter in the Kampong Cham province. She works in a grocery store, earning around $7 per day, while her husband has a business selling rubber and earns approximately $5 a day. Mrs. Choun would like to use this loan to purchase more grocery items to meet her clients’ demands.

loans.use: groceries to stock store

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en: Sorn L., 31, is married and has a business selling grocery products from her home. On average, she makes $3.50 a day and her husband earns around $2.50 a day by purchasing rubber from individual growers and reselling it to the market-wholesaler. Mrs. Sorn L. would like to use this loan to purchase more grocery items to meet her clients’ demands.

loans.use: groceries

loans.name: Ilhom

texts.ru: Ильхом парень который занимается развозкой жвачек "орбит", по районам,Исфара,Истаравшан.Он является поставщиком фирмы WRIGLEY.Его оборот увеличился вдвое после кредитов Микроинвест. Ильхом говорит, что благодаря кредитам у него улучшилась семейная жизнь,и увеличился оборот.Сам Ильхом мастер по евроремонту жилых домов,кроме своего бизнеса он в сезон будет принимать заказы.Ильхом благодарит KIVA за финансирование.
texts.en:
Ilhom M. is a young man who works distributing Orbit chewing gum in the Isfara and Istaravshan districts. He contracts with the Wrigely company. His sales volume doubled in size after the loan from Microinvest. Ilhom says that thanks to the loan his family's quality of life has improved, and sales volume has increased. Ilhom is himself an expert in european style remodeling of apartment buildings, and in addition to his business, in season he will contract out. He thanks Kiva for the financing.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Chewing gun

loans.name: Chhem

texts.en: Chhem K. is 26 years old and lives with her husband in the Kampong Chhnang province. She works in a grocery store, making around US$6 of profit per day, while her husband, wearing the blue shirt pictured here, earns about US$3.50 a day working as a mechanic, fixing TVs and radios. He also fixes the second-hand products and resells them to people in the area. This couple has one little child. Chhem would like to take out a loan to purchase old televisions, radios and tape recorders and other tools. The rest of the loan will be used to expand grocery products.

loans.use: To purchase old televisions, radios and mechanic tools.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock her store

loans.name: Pili

texts.en:
Pili has been a bites seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for many years. She belongs to I'Wote loan group (Group code 2048).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $155. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her business. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business. 

Pili is 45 years old, married, and has three children: ages 30, 26 and 24

loans.use: To buy more items to expand her business.

loans.name: Mrs. Noeurn Vean Village Bank Group

texts.en: Sixteen people living in Saeprambei village in Kampong Cham province make up this village bank loan, and they will use the loan for various purposes. Mrs. Noeurn V., the 45-year-old village bank president, is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Her husband, Mr. Sorn S., is a laborer who has only a little salary to support his family. In order to improve their standard of living, Mrs. Noeurn V. decided to ask for a loan to purchase grocery goods to re-sell to earn more income. She has three children who are laborers in different positions.

loans.use: To purchase grocery goods to re-sell to earn more income.

loans.name: Luzmienda

texts.en:
Luzmienda L., 56, is a widow with five children, all married --  one of whom is working abroad, two were not able to finish college. 

She lives in a small barrio of Sta. Cruz, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. Her main source of income is duck-raising. She started with 20 ducks and has grown the business with 350 ducks.  She sells duck eggs to the neighboring localities. 

She had already nine loan availments from PMPC. With the Kiva loan, she wants to buy more ducks to produce eggs thus, increasing her profit as well.  

She hopes to help her married children financially, the other two (2) to finish college and enough money to get her by when she gets old and could no longer work.

loans.use: Additional capital in purchasing ducks

loans.name: Heang

texts.en: Heang C. Eng is 37 years old and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province. Since 1999, she and her husband have worked as recyclers, together making $4 every day. This couple has two children, both  students. (Mrs. Heang is pictured here with her husband). They will use their loan to purchase recyclables from locals to sell to the wholesale recycler.

loans.use: recyclable materials

loans.name: Mwajuma

texts.en:
For the past three years, Mwajuma has been running a small store in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar where she sells charcoal and firewood. She belongs to Uvivu si kazi loan group (group code 2005).  She currently realizes an average monthly profit of $80. Every day she works at her place of business for 14 hours. She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and firewood. She is hoping that this loan will help her increase her profits and expand her business. 

Mwajuma is 26 years old and married. She has four children, ages 12 years, 7years, 6 years, and 1 month.

loans.use: To buy charcoal and firewood for resale.

loans.name: Savoen

texts.en: Mrs. Savoen K. is a villager in Boeung village in Kandal province. She is a 49-year-old widow with two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while the other is attending the local school. She is a sculptor. Since her career is doing well, she decided to ask for a loan to purchase more sculpture tools to earn more income to support her family's living.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to purchase more sculpture tools.

loans.name: Akbarhon

texts.ru: Акбархон мужчина в возрасте 39лет имеет 2 детей,жена работает в столовой поваром.Акбархон занимается продажей различных аксессуаров для сотовых трубок и их самих.Он арендует небольшой ларёк в центре Худжанда.У него свои постоянные клиенты , которые крупными партиями закупают его товар и перепродают сами.Акбархон получив займ хочет пополнить свой товар, новыми видами , марками сотовых трубок и и различных аксессуаров.
texts.en:
Akbarhon H. is a 39 year old man with two children, whose wife works as a cafeteria chef. Akbarhon sells various accessories for cellular phones as well as the phones themselves. He rents a small booth in downtown Khudzhand. He has regular customers who buy his goods in large quantities and resell them. Akbarhon wants to use a loan to augment his inventory with new types and brands of cellular phone and various accessories.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Mobile phone accessories

loans.name: Yean

texts.en: Yean R., 66, is a widow who lives in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She grows and sells rice and earns approximately $4 every day. She receives some support from two of her childR. (pictured here). One is a farmer and the other is a garment factory worker. Mrs. Yean is asking for a loan to purchase a grinding machine. She will rent this mill as a service to the local farmers.

loans.use: grinding machine

loans.name: Choem

texts.en: Mrs. Choem K. is a 45-year-old widow and she lives in Thlos village in Takeo province. She has a child who is attending the local school. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. In this plantation, she earns little income to provide a good life for her child; thus, she decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to build a house to live in.

loans.use: To build a house to live in.

loans.name: Eang

texts.en: Eang C. is 25 years old and is pictured here with her husband at home. She has a business selling fish in the market and earns about $4 a day. Her husband makes $7 by working as a moto-taxi driver. She and her husband have one child who is too young to attend school. Mrs. Eang is asking for a loan to purchase a new motorbike for her husband to operate as a motor-taxi.

loans.use: To purchase motorbike to use as a moto-taxi

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock her shop

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Fatma has been a firewood seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for the past 2 years. She belongs to the Hatuyumbishwi loan group (Group code 2025). She currently makes an average monthly profit of $40. Every day she works for 14 hours.  She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more firewood for her business. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and to save money for future use.

Fatma is 45 years old, divorced, and has six children: ages between 26 and 17.

loans.use: To buy more firewood for her business.

loans.name: Mastura

texts.ru: Мастура женщина 34 лет , имеет двоих детей, муж электрик.Мастура закупает хлопковое масло оптом с маслозаводов и продаёт в разлив в розницу.Мастура продаёт качественное рафинированое масло,поэтому у неё очень хороший поток клиентов.Благодаря этому бизнесу у неё улучшилось состояние проживания семьи увеличился товарооборот.Мастура постоянный клиент Микроинвест
texts.en:
Mastura is a 34 year old woman with two children. Her husband is an electrician. Mastura buys cottonseed oil wholesale from a factory and sells it retail, on tap. Because Mastura sells such high quality purified oil she has a good stream of customers. Thanks to this business her family's living situation has improved and sales have increased. Mastura is a regular Microinvest client.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Foods

loans.name: Aim

texts.en: Aim M. is a widow who lives with two children in Kampong Cham, Cambodia She grows and sells mushrooms in the village and makes about $6 per day. Her two children are employed as garment factory workers. She would like to use this loan to purchase rice to resell for a profit.

loans.use: To buy bulk rice for resale

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
For the last two years, Salama has made a living selling clothes and fish in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar. She is a member of the Tusongembele loan group, and makes about $185 a month working for 16 hours a day. She is applying for her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes and fish to sell. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to expand her business.

Salama is 45 years old, married and has seven children, ages 7 to 30.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and fish to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe S. is a rice grower. She saves some of her harvest for family consumption and sells the rest to some of the rice traders in their village. Farming is her life. Her parents taught her to plant and harvest. Because of her farm, she was able to send her four children to school. She was also able to provide adequately for their needs. Her husband, Jurlito S., is also a farmer. They work together to raise all their children. They have big dreams for their family. Hard work and capital are their only means.

Fe is asking CEVI for a loan to buy fertilizers and herbicides for her farm. Through her loan, she will be able to increase her yield. When that happens, she will have more to give to her children. She also is considering looking into some other possible income areas. The loan will help a lot to start another line of business.

CEVI helps Fe to start a new business and expand her farm. CEVI provides her with the credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage that CEVI gives to all its clients.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and herbicides.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy one more cow for breeding.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Ms. Theresa F. hails from Pandan, Antique. She is member of Antique Northwest Branch of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI).  Because of the limited employment opportunities in Antique the couple sacrificed to be far away from each other such that her husband needs to work as a construction worker in Manila.

She used to tend a variety store but due tobad debts this did not succeed.  She then shifted to hog fattening and also put up a barbecue stand Her  barbecue business is doing well, with the students of the nearby school as her primary customers. She is still waiting for her hog to have piglets. She is therefore requesting for a loan of PHP 5,000 to purchase two piglets and two sacks of feeds to jumpstart her hog-fattening business.
 
At the moment she dream to have a piggery and a barbecue stall near the school so that she will be able to send her children to college, get a good job, and have a better future. She is very thankful to ASHI because little by little she noticed the improvements in her life.  She also acquired self confidence in the process and is no longer shy nor timid.

loans.use: To purchase 2 piglets and 2 sacks of feeds

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha has made a living selling soup and small side dishes in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for the last 15 years. She belongs to the Hatuchoki loan group, and currently earns an average profit of $155 a month by workling 16 hours a day. She is applying her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items to sell. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business. 

Asha is 39 years old, married and has three children ages 4, 14 and 18. She also cares for two other dependants.

loans.use: To buy more items and expand her business.

loans.name: Liem's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Liem P. is a group leader of four members who all live in Thmey village in Kampong Chhnang province. She is a grocer. Her husband, Mr. Seng Socheat, is a vet in the local village. Aside from this career, he is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate lotus. In this plantation, he does not have enough lotus seed to grow. In order to deal with this problem, Mrs. Liem P. decided to ask for a loan to buy more lotus seed for her husband’s plantation. She hopes to increase income and improve their living conditions with this loan. She is 30 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are enrolled in the local school, while the youngest one is too young to work or study.

All the members in this group loan have end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan's term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. These allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more lotus seed for her husband’s plantation.

loans.name: Nia Njema Group

texts.en:
Angela has made a living selling food in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for the last year. She earns an average monthly profit of $185, and works for 14 hours a day.  She is seeking her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items to sell to her customers. She is hoping that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to expand her business.       

Angela is 32 years old, divorced and has a ten-year-old child. She will be sharing this loan with the other member of her lending group, Faldia D., who also runs a business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To bu more food items to sell to her customers.

loans.name: By

texts.en: Mr. By Ben is a villager in Chi Prang village in Kampong Chhnang province. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. In this plantation, he earns only a little income to support his household. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan to buy a piece of land to cultivate rice to earn more income. His wife, Mrs. Un Kit, is a pig breeder. Mr. By Ben is a 25-year-old father of a child who is too young to work or study. His wife is presented with him in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a piece of land to cultivate rice to earn more income.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy sacks of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Thorn

texts.en: Thorn B., 24, is married and lives with her child in the Prey Veng province. She and her husband (pictured here) are farmers who typically make about US$1 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been difficult for them to handle. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Thorn B. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase land to increase her farming production. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: To purchase farmland

loans.name: Batuli

texts.en:
Batuli has sold charcoal, juice and various types of food in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for many years. She belongs to the Allah Karim loan group, and currently earns an average monthly profit of $80. Every day she works for 14 hours. She is seeking her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and juice to sell to her customers. She hopes that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to expand her business.

Batuli is 35 years old, married and has two children.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and juice to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Sie

texts.en: Mrs. Sie K. lives in Kouk Penh village in Kampong Chhnang province. She is a grocer who owns a small grocery store. Her husband, Mr. Puth Savy, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Even though they have different careers, they still earn little income to support their family's demands. Mrs. Sie K. is applying for a loan to buy an electricity machine to light the house at night. She is 46 years old and the mother of seven children, one of whom is a beautician, another is a farmer, another one stays at home to do house work, while the others are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To buy an electricity machine to light the house at night.

loans.name: Hidaya

texts.en:
Hidaya has made a living selling curtains and shoes in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for the last four years. She belongs to the M'Mola loan group and currently earns an average monthly profit of $90 by working 12 hours a day at her job. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more shoes to sell to her customers. She is hoping that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to expand her business.  

Hidaya is 36 years old, married and has five children ages 1, 6, 9, 12 and 14 years old

loans.use: To expand her business by buying more shoes to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en:
Tatu has owned a small charcoal store in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for many years. She belongs to the Nia njema loan group, and currently earns an average monthly profit of $50. Every day she works at her busines for 14 hours. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal to sell to her customers. She is hoping that this loan will allow her to increase her profits and grow her business.    

Tatu is 33 years old, married, and has three children ages 4, 7 and 13.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Hamida

texts.en:
Hamida has owned and operated a small charcoal and firewood store in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for the last two years. She belongs to the Kumekucha loan group, and currently earns an average monthly profit of $40. Every day she works at her business for 14 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and firewood to sell. She hopes that through this loan she will be able to increase her profits and grow her business.    

Hamida is 49 years old, divorced and has seven children.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood for her business

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en: Mrs. Cheng K. is a villager in Prey Sak village in Kampong Chhnang province. She and her husband, Mr. Um Nath, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice. Even though they try to work hard, they still earn little income to provide a good life for their family. Thus, Mrs. Cheng K. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to build a house for her family. She is a 50-year-old mother of three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the other stays at home to do housework.

loans.use: To add to her savings to build a house for her family.

loans.name: Sangin

texts.ru: Назаров Сангин житель Вахдата. Возраст 51 год, женат и имеет четверых детей. Образование среднее. Уже 10 лет занимается торговлей продуктов питания. Имеет свой магазин  ,где торгует продуктами питания ,поставляемыми из города Душанбе. Сангин имеет много клиентов , так как его товар имеет большой спрос и кроме этого у него доступные цены и свежие продукты. В данный момент он решил открыть отдел одежды и парфюмерии , поэтому обратился к нам за кредитом.Это поможет ему привлечь новых клиентов и увеличить доходы своего бизнеса. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 10 месяцев.
texts.en:
Sangin N. lives in Vahdat. He is 51 years old, married and has four children. He has a secondary education. He has been in the business of selling food products for 10 years and owns a store. The products are delivered from Dushanbe. Sangin has many clients because his products are fresh and in high demand, and his prices are affordable. Currently, he decided to open a clothing and perfume department and needs a loan for this purpose. The expansion would help Sangin to attract new clients and increase his business profit. He will be able to repay the loan within 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase assortment

loans.name: Jaleel

texts.en:
Jaleel K.  lives in Bubal Afghanistan. He is 32 years old, married with two children. Jaleel is a hard working carpenter.
He has requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani for the term of 12 months because he wants to expand his business. He wants to buy necessary material and complete the  stock for his shop.     
Jaleel is very happy about this small loan process in Afghanistan that wants to help  poor people. He wants to thank all lenders to AFSG and Kiva.

loans.use: He wants to buy necessary material and complete the stock for his shop

loans.name: Khis

texts.en: Khis N. is 55 years old and lives with her husband. He is pictured here with a big grinding machine, in Prey Veng province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about US$ 5 per day. This couple has two children and both of them are employed as police officers. Besides growing and selling rice, this couple also has a grinding service from their home. To make more money, Mrs. Khis would like to use this loan to replace their present machine with a bigger one.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding mill

loans.name: Gultakin

texts.en: Gultakin M. is 35-year-old woman who has been breeding calves for the last 12 years. Gultakin is married and has two children. Cattle breeding is the only financial source for her family. Gultakin purchases baby calves, fattens them and then sells to the local people. She applied for $1200 to purchase two calves and expand her business.

loans.use: Purchase two calves.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mrs. Mom P., 43, and her husband, Mr. Sarum Seng, 48, married in 1987 and have five sons. Four of them are in school and the other one stays at home to assist his parents in farming. Besides her children, she also has an elderly mother living with her. The family lives along National Road Number One about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mom and her husband are farmers. They grow vegetables and flowers in their farmland in the village and sell them to the middleman in the village. They hope that their business will be able to support their children's further education.

Mom is requesting for her first loan of US$ 500 to purchase fertilizer and pesticides for growing vegetables and flowers.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticides for growing vegetables and flowers

loans.name: Vohid

texts.ru: Вохид мужчина 46 лет, женат имеет четверых детей.Сам работает завхозом в школе.Его зарплата не хватает для проживания его семь, поэтому он имеет свой семейный бизнес.Ему по бизнесу помогает его сын,который на фото,сам Вохид вовремя мониторинга был в отъезде за товаром.Вохида не возможно застать на месте деятельности ,т.к. он всегда занят по работе и по завозу товара.Его сын взрослый молодой человек и очень ответственный,отец ему полностью доверяет бизнес в его отсутствии.Кредит хочет получитьдля увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en:
Vohid is a 46 year old man who is married and has four children. He is an office manager in a school. His salary is too small to support his family, so he started a family business. His son (pictured in the photograph as Vohid was away transporting goods during the monitoring session) helps with the business. Vohid can never be found on site since he is always busy with work and moving goods. His son is a mature young man and very responsible, whom his father completely entrusts the business to in his absence. A loan is requested for expanding inventory selection.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Toiletry retail

loans.name: Cheab

texts.en:
Cheab S. is 29 years old and lives at home,in Prey Veng province, with her husband and two young children. She is a good housewife, doing housework and cooking for her family members. Her husband, who pictured here with his wife and two children, is a construction foreman. He has been doing construction since 1998 and is able to make about US$ 15 every day.

Mrs. Cheab S. would like to take out a loan to purchase construction tools for her husband. In the future, she wants to open a grocery store to earn additional income to help raise their standard of living.

loans.use: Construction tools for her husband

loans.name: Sokchea

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokchea B. (on the right in the picture with her sister), 29, married in 2005 and has one young son. She lives along National Road Number One about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Sokchea has been a garment factory worker for almost eleven years. She doesn't have her own transportation and she always spends a lot of money for transportation fees such as motor taxi or motor remorque (a motorbike with a trailer at the back) and so on. So she is asking for her first loan of US$ 1,200 to purchase a motorcycle to ride to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to ride to work.

loans.name: Erdene

texts.en:
Erdene N. is a 40-year-old man who lives with his wife and four children. He has two sons and two daughters. His sons, aged 16 and 18, are going to high school. One of his daughters is 12 years old and goes to elementary school. His other daughter is 13-years-old and handicapped, therefore homebound for many years.

Erdene's wife makes the traditional Mongolian "deel" -- a type of silken robe worn by women and men -- as well as vests, which he then sells. During the Lunar New Year, many people wear "deel" and traditional vests. She gets many orders for sewing "deel" every year before the Lunar New Year. Right now, she doesn't have money to buy materials; therefore she's been making deals with her clients to provide her materials. However, from this year on, they are planning to take a loan to buy their own materials for "deel" and traditional vests.

Erdene will sell "deel" and the traditional vests that his wife sews at a higher price. Erdene said: "My children are growing well now. We had really hard times when my children were young, between the ages of 1 and 6. What I and my wife are most worried about is our handicapped daughter's future. We are working hard even now to make her future better."

loans.use: To buy silk for making Mongolian traditional robes called "deel"

loans.name: Narmina

texts.en: Narmina M. is 25 years old and full of enthusiasm and energy. She has been breeding cattle for the last two years, ever since her mother's illness required that she take over the family chores. She tries her best to raise and fatten the calves with the hopes she'll make enough income to cover the basic needs of her old parents. Narmina would like to expand her herd by purchasing two baby calves and fodder for the cattle. She has applied for a 1200 USD loan. The loan will help increase her income and bring financial stability to her family.

loans.use: Purchase two baby calves and fodder

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Kong P., 34, is married and lives with her husband in Prey Veng province. She stays at home doing housework and cooking for her family members. Her husband is the head of the household who is entirely responsible for living costs every day. He is 36 years old and has been operating a motor-taxi business for about 9 years. On average, he makes US$ 2 every day. This couple has two young children. Mrs. Kong P. is asking for a loan to replace their old and unreliable motorbike with a better one for her husband to use to operate a motor-taxi.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband's business

loans.name: Savat

texts.en:
Mr. Savat Duong, 37, and his wife, Mrs. Kim-ei Sun, 35, who live along National Road Number One about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1995 and have three children: one son and two daughters. Two of their children are in school and the other one is still young.

Savat and his wife have been growing cauliflowers for three years. It’s a skill they learned from their villagers. As a future plan, Savat hopes to become a mason and support his children's further education. He is requesting his first loan of $1,200 to purchase fertilizer, pesticide and diesel for growing cauliflowers.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, pesticide, and diesel for growing cauliflowers

loans.name: Aziza

texts.en:
Aziza has run a small charcoal and firewood store in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for the last four years. She belongs to the Tusichukiane loan group, and currently earns an average monthly profit of $125. She works at her  business for 12 hours a day. She is seeking her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and firewood for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.    

Aziza is 45 years old, married, and has six children ages 2, 10, 18, 21, 23 and 25.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood for her business.

loans.name: Tusichukiane Group

texts.en:
For the last three years Asha has owned a small store in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar, where she sells firewood and various food items. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $310 by working 14 hours a day.  She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more firewood to sell to her customers. She is hoping that this loan will allow her to increase her profits and grow her business.  

Asha is 30 years old, married and has three children ages 8, 2 and 8 months. She also cares for three other dependents. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, whose names are Mtumwa, Nizuma, Tatu and Sada. Each woman also runs a small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more firewood for her business.

loans.name: Regalado

texts.en:
Regalado D. grows rice on his farm. His co-farmers help him plow his field and they help each other to prepare the soil for planting season. Regalado has a beautiful wife, Ma. Leah D., and three children. He worries a lot about how he can send his children to school. His harvest is what Regalado depends on to raise his growing family. He started his business using a small parcel of land which he inherited from his parents. Some of the harvest goes to family consumption while the rest is sold for additional income.

Regalado is requesting a loan from CEVI to expand his farm. He will use the loan to buy fertilizers, herbicides and seeds. His loan will help him have a better harvest. He is planning to buy more land and increase his farm size.

CEVI helps Regalado sustain his farm. He has access to the credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage which CEVI provides to all its clients.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and herbicides for his farm.

loans.name: Navuth

texts.en:
Mrs. Navuth M., 42, and her husband, Mr. Heng Hai, 41, who live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penn, the capital city of Cambodia, married in 1989 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. Three of their children are in school, and the eldest daughter does farming.

Navuth has been selling vegetables for one year and has been selling fruit and farming since she was married. She sells guavas and mangoes. Her husband is a chef. He sometimes cooks for wedding ceremonies and other ceremonies in his village and in Phnom Penh. Navuth is requesting her first loan of US$ 1,000 to purchase mangoes on contract for re-sale.

loans.use: To purchase mangoes on contract for re-sale

loans.name: Teng

texts.en: Teng S. is 28 years old and stays at home doing housework and taking care of her young child. She and her husband have been married for about five years and live in Prey Veng province. To support the family, her husband has a business selling cows. On average, he makes about US$ 2 in profit per day. Mrs. Teng S. is asking for a loan to purchase cows for her husband for re-sell.

loans.use: To purchase cows for re-sale

loans.name: Zoid

texts.ru: Зоид ответственный клиент в Микроинвест с 2006 года.Всё это время он пунктуально и целенаправлено использует свой займ.Он бизнесмен с опытом работы уже 15 лет на рынке.Зоид имеет своих постоянных поставщиков , которые сами поставляют товар ему на место торговли.Поэтому Зоид не тратит транспортные расходы на завоз товаров.Сейчас он хочет получив займ закупить пачковый , чай и несколько видов конфет.
texts.en:
Zoid has been a reliable Microinvest client since 2006. He has always been punctual and goal oriented with the loans he receives. He is a businessman with 15 years of experience at the market. Zoid has his own regular suppliers who deliver goods to the place of sales. This way Zoid does not waste money on transportation of the goods. Now he wants a loan to buy tea packets and several kinds of candy.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grocery supplies

loans.name: Vuthy

texts.en:
Mr. Vuthy B., 53, and his wife, Mrs. Phalla Sok, 54, who live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia, married in 1979 and have five children: three sons and two daughters. One of their children is a garment factory worker; two children are in school and another one is a chef.

Vuthy has been a truck driver since 1993. He can earn about US$ 120 for each journey. His wife stays at home to take care of their children. He is requesting a loan of US$ 1,000 to purchase a motorbike for his children to ride to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for his children to drive to work.

loans.name: Roza

texts.en: Roza M. is a 40-year-old single woman who has bred cattle for the last seven years. Roza lives with her parents who are on pension now, so she is the breadwinner of the family. Cattle breeding brings her stable income, but it is just enough to cover the basic needs of her and her parents. Roza would like to increase her income to improve her family's living conditions. To help her achieve this goal, Roza has applied for a 1200 USD loan that she will use to purchase two calves and fodder for the cattle.

loans.use: Purchase two calves and fodder

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en: Cheng S., 30, is married and lives in the Prey Veng province with her husband, pictured here. She has two young children and works with her husband selling rock and construction materials in the village. She realizes a profit of approximately US$3  every day. Cheng S. would like to take out a loan to purchase an electric drill. She will rent he drill when she is not using it herself to break up rock for sale.

loans.use: To purchase an electric drill.

loans.name: Tuyatsetseg

texts.en:
Tuyatsetseg G. is a 33-year-old woman who lives with her husband and son in a "ger" in Mongolia (a ger is the traditional, nomadic form of housing in Mongolia; a ger district is where many people have settled in these homes, forming a sort of ad hoc suburb).

The family owns the land where their ger is located. Her son is 13; he goes to elementary school. She, Tuyatsetseg, runs a clothing stall with her husband at Narantuul, Mongolia's biggest outdoor market, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city. During the fall, winter, and spring they sell gloves. In summer, they sell sunglasses. They own, rather than rent, their stall. They would like a loan to buy another stall in the clothing section of the Narantuul market. Together with her husband, Tuyatsetseg is planning to renovate her house this coming spring. She has a hard-working and humble personality.

loans.use: To buy gloves to increase business inventory

loans.name: Bimkubwa

texts.en:
Bimkubwa has made a living selling juice in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for the last 20 years. She belongs to the Muungano loan group and currently earns an average profit of $50 a month. Every day she works at her business for 14 hours. She is seeking her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy bread to sell to her customers. She is hoping that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to expand her business.  

Bimkubwa is 40 years old, married and has six children ages 7 to 20 years old.

loans.use: To expand her business by buying more items to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Tuvumiliane Group

texts.en:
Inne makes a living selling fish in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar, and earns an average monthly profit of $125. She works at her business for 14 hours a day. Inne is seeking her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more fish to sell to her customers. She is hoping that this loan will allow her to increase her profits and expand her business.  

Inne is 23 years old, married and has three children aged 6, 4 and 10 months. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow loan group member, Mwanaisha, who also owns a small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en: Cheng Y. is 36 years old, pictured here with her husband and little child, and has a business raising ducks for eggs to sell in the market. Every day, her husband transports duck eggs to sell at the market. On average, this couple earns a combined income of around US$ 5 per day. Mrs. Cheng Y. is asking for a loan to purchase a trailer for her husband to transport their duck eggs; any remainder will be used to purchase feed for the ducks.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer to transport their eggs to market
